reviews.review:
Tranquil place - a must for all the Ummah. Turkey has done a superb job in restoring the Mazar's of all Sahaba and build mosques around them.
Very well kept and very clean, its a must for all the Muslims.
Adjacent to the mosque is the Mazar of Hazat Ayub Ansari - a prominent companion of our Prophet Sallallahu Alaihi Wasallam

Shrine and Masjid of Hazrat Abu Ayub Ansari (RA). It was the place my mother recommended before my departure. I went directly there after reaching at hotel and got fresh up. My hotel was at Beyazit area and I walked to Eminonue squre. From there bought a bus card and asked the number from a window. Then sat in the bus and after 15 minutes reached at the complex. After visiting went to the Piarlote park situated behind. Sat there and had Turkish tea.
Spitual experience!. Eyup Sultan was Holy prophet's companion. A very emotional experience for me. Must go there at prayer time. Superb experience! Will visit again on my next trip.

Go And see before teleferik. Go see beautiful free mosque and if your muslim, i guess ull enjoy praying there, surrounded by a small local market, a must go before you go up the hill by teleferik to the MUST GO CAFE up the hill, the teleferik ride is small and disappointing but the view from the cafe is more than breathtaking and the drinks and food is simple but more than awesome
Beautiful. Super crowded but beautiful shrine of historical significance. It was hard to look through the crowds but worth the trip

Spiritual . Hazrat Eyub Sultan blessed to have been, went 3-times in 10 days, beautiful atmosphere, bazaar nearby too for gifts etc. Take the tram from Sultanahmet and get off at Eminiou, cross over to bus station catch 99A and get off and Eyub mosque. Don't forget to get a travel pass and you can use it on buses/trams and ferries.

A must visit in Istanbul. Venerated by locals and muslims in general, this is definitively a place to visit. A great place for contemplation and nice local culture flavour. Not many tourists go there and there are plenty of cats roaming around.

Busy yet peaceful. For Muslims, this is a place of religious importance, as the complex contains the tomb of an important companion of the Holy Prophet. You'll see newly married couples coming for blessings, little boys dressed extravagantly (awaiting their circumcision!) and pilgrims from around Turkey. Its in a residential district and you'll see a lot more skull caps and headscarves than you'll ever see in SultanAhmet or Taksim. Visit to get a sense of religious Turkey. Its an easy bus ride from the Eminonu bus station - just ask anyone how to get to Eyup and ask the bus conductor to let you know when you're there. Shouldn't take more than 15 minutes.

Very traditional neighbourhood. A very traditional neighbourhood... wooden houses...outdoor restaurants, big public square with a fountain... the mosque itself is very interesting and of course the cable ride up to Pierre Loti Cafe is worth the travel.
Spiritual Expereince. It was a great experience for me to go there. As a Muslim it is a site of great religious importance for me as it is the tomb of the disciple of our holy Prophet.

a real pilgramage place. A real sense of people on a holy pilgramage to here and an important place for believers but they are happy to have tourists looking over their shoulders. Does not take long to pass through but a proper sense of the real Islam and the peace that goes with it can be felt here.

Great day visit. . A visit to Eyup is essential for both Muslims and non Muslims alike. For Muslims it is believed that the tomb of Ayyub al Ansari, a companion of the Prophet Muhammad, is located there. Historians believe it was discovered by Mehmet the Conquerer prior to the conquest of Constantinople. Though the Blue Mosque is considered as the flagship mosque of Istanbul the holiest mosque is the Eyup Sultan Mosque. The ambience of the surrounding area with the food and gift shops is great. It is also located close to the cable car which accesses the Pierre Loti restaurant with fabulous views over looking the Golden Horn. It is well worth the visit but the queues can be fairly long. Alternatively there is a pathway access to the top. We decided to take the Cable car up and path back down and the kids loved the walk. From Sultanahmet Eyup is easily accessed by ferry which only cost 4 TL which is added bonus with great views of Istanbul from the Golden Horn. From SultanAhmet catch the tram to Eminonu. A short distance is a ferry port Eminönü Haliç İskelesi where you can catch a ferry to Eyup. The mosque complex is only 5 minute walk from the port. We went with a view of spending half a day but ended up spending most of the day there. All in all it is great day trip if you include ferry ride, cable car and the visit to Pierre Loti.

People and nature in a peacefully landscape. This view of Istanbul is certainly surrounded by specials feelings. Not only because there is an important cemetery based on Sultan Eyup tomb, but for the incredible landscape you see from the hill and an incredible layout of tombs and parks that makes you forget where you are, or even better, it makes you understand than life and death are the two faces of our coins.

Holy place in Istanbul. This is the most holiest place in istanbul, the tomb of Hazrat Abu Ayub Ansari (a companion of our Prophet PBUH). Just opposite the tomb is the Ayub ansari masjid which is reflecting traditional architecture with dombs & pencil minaret. The adjoining graveyard is reserved for burying sultans & high rank officials (even of todays era).

very interesting to visit. the area is full of traditional and religious activities in the mosque and near around , the kids loved playing around the fountain , and with the pigeons , many cheap shops there , and the food is so delicious , you can eat the turkish traditional food for a very good price , we enjoyed it

Beautiful and serene!. A bit off the beaten path, but very worthwhile visiting. Not a real touristy place, more suitable for a pilgrimage to a holy site. This is a good place to observe an authentic Turkish environment, away from the camera click-click of busloads of clueless tourists. One of the older cemeteries is just up the hill. Venture in and lose yourself in the eternity of those at rest. There are many markers with words of wisdom set in the walls that line the path to the cafe, which offers the best view of Istanbul.

Eyup Sultan Mosqu. Eyup Sultan history should be googled before visiting this spiritual cite to thourghly enjoy the visit.. Head scarf should be worn when visiting the mosque. The walkway leads to cable cart with stunning views, its a mininal cost but worth the visit.

Spiritual Place. This a spiritual place. One can easily reach it by bus from Eminounu 99 and 99A. Is a little walk from the Bus stop. The Masoleum of Hazrat Abu Ayub Ansari is in the courtyard of the Mosque. Great Experience.

Combine this and Pierre Loti. Another great mosque with great surroundings. When you have finished this visit, take the funicular up to Pierre Loti at the top and enjoy a drink and a beautiful panoramic view.
beautiful. I love to visit moskeés because they bring out a feeling of aw and wonder because of its history and the fact that its still has its use left in this very modern world.

Peaceful mosque. So much respect for our beloved prophet's companion, the district and mosque named after Hazrat Abu Ayoob ansari.
The chosen host of our prophet on his arrival in Madina, ge us laid to rest here during the conquest of Constantinople.
A spiritual and place.

Beautiful spiritual place. This place had a beautiful sense of spiritualness attached to it people from all over were visiting. We took a ferry over rather than other transport. It was very busy an takes around 30 mins, once you get off follow the hustle bustle of people through the market stalls until you reach a square. There we prayed Asar salah and then went to the mezar to offer our respects and make dua for all. Stunning mosque inside the mens section attached to the mezar. Not far is the telephonic (something like that) cable cars that take you up to a view point. Nice views but ques can be very long. Theres only 4 cable cars each seats 8 people. We waited for ages and missed our last ferry back, but worth a visit if you fancy it. Enjoy.
Recommend to visit in Sabah time . The Sultan Ahmed mosque is special place to pray Sabah / Fajr sale time. Many people came to the mosque like to juma. I was very impressed by this.

Eyup Sultan Mosque. I have enjoyed wondering around this area so much. It is very classic lovely area. The people are superb and the coffee shops, restaurants and shops are so fabulous. The complete mood was so peaceful at this beautiful area.

Remember our great people. Visited Eyup mosque. Very big with many visitors. Nice washing area - Wodoo - and drinking water in many taps. People do visit the mosque for pray then the tomb to read Al Fatiha.

Awesome history . WOW what a place to visit. So beautiful and peaceful. The tomb is a must. Unbelievable piece of history. Easy to get to from Eminomu by ferry. Although there are no signs in English still very easy to find. Set in a lovely location within walking distance of everything u need. Walk to the cable car for amazing views of the golden horn from Pierre Loti cafe.

Loved it. This is a great place especially for muslims. Its clean, organized and fun if you are the type that enjoys the basic life style of sitting opposite to the fountain on the steps & eating your corn or ice-creams.Lots of cafes & restaurants around which we didn't try. Simit Saray is a good one though. We prayed in the mosque, very clean and well maintained. An interesting experience for muslim tourists.

Wonderful Mosque!. Take the ferry from Eminonu and see the tomb as well as the mosque which holds one of the richest Muslim history in Istanbul. It is definitely one of the most crowded mosques of the city which is normally packed with hundreds, maybe thousands,of worshipers every day. The environment is awesome and you really feel privileged to have visited this place.

A Important historical site. An interesting historical tomb to visit. A little hard to travel to as we took a bus then had to walk up to the tomb.The site was busy with locals. No guided tour and very little signage around in engish to help ascertain what various monuments were. Guidebooks said very little about the site so maybe a tour guide who had knowledge of the history here would really help.

An amazing place. We took the ferry from Eminomu without thinking that this was lunchtime on the last Friday of Ramazan. As a result we couldn't see the tomb and only spent 2 minutes in the mosque before being shushed out (not because we weren't Muslims but because it was getting too crowded). The whole area was packed with thousands of pilgrims, the Imam was preaching, ice-cream and juice sellers were doing a roaring trade. In fact the atmosphere was totally electric, thrilling and very welcoming - possibly the highspot of our entire visit. But we must return at a quieter time to see the mosque properly!
very good. The place is big. Mosque is very authentic. Location is very good. You can go this mosque by car, bus or ship from the sea side.

great and free. One of the places where people hear the spiritual tranquility of the lovely month of Ramadan in the crowd of people how to live such a wonderful place to experience a super nice feeling
less

Beautiful small mosque away from the main tourist trail. Well worth catching a ferry to see Eyup mosque and then walk up through the the cemetery to Pierre Loti cafe for great views.
The tile work on the mosque interior of beaufitul.

Every nice mosque and surrounding shopping centres. The history of this mosque mesmerised me as a Muslim and the peace and tranquility is just out of this world. As soon as you step outside there is a good shopping area and lively feeling and very vibrant

Steeped in Awe. Everything about this place is jaw-dropping.You don't need to be religious to visit, it is a known and well visited tourist hot spot. I visited with my ex-mother in law and with her being very religious I was treated to a full hour of prayer with her and the other ladies. I found it to be a very humbling place and after prayer was over we had the full tour. The architecture and mosaic tiling was breathtaking. It is free to enter and you must take off your shoes and add a hijab (hair covering scarf) before you enter.

A spiritual experience - Eyup Mosque. I would recommend going during the Ramadan time or maybe just before or after the prayer time. It's bustling with locals. You can even catch the start or end of the prayer time. It really adds to the experience. Also, it's an architectural beauty. I would say that the Eyup mosque is more beautiful than the Blue Mosque. Also, you can get a more authentic feeling of a Mosque than the Blue Mosque. The latter is far too touristy.

Must go for Friday Prayer. I went to Eyup Sultan Mosque to offer my Friday prayer. The mosque was so crowded that first I wasn't able to find a place to sit but when I got a place it was so difficult to pray. My suggestion would be that go there early to secure a convenient place. After the prayer people start lining up for the Eyup Sultan Mausoleum, good part of it is that no one was jumping the line and pushing. Before going inside the mausoleum, plastic bags were given to the visitors to keep their shoes in it while inside the place. The line was moving and everyone got a good view.
Very nice. Big space, nice location and a good atmosphere with shops all around We went there by ferry and enjoyed our time, specially going up the hill where the café is

Epic Mosque. This mosque is a little bit out of the way from the central areas of Istanbul - but easily connected to by bus. It's an epic Mosque, with a rich history and unique design. It also houses a shrine of the Sultan. There's also good places to eat right outside!
cultural. Very intestine experience. Folks wear respectful clothing long sleeves and trousers and a pazhmina or shawl for hair.

Very Spiritual Peaceful Place. A Surreal experience, very peaceful found a lot of contentent within the courtyard of the mosque and the actual tomb where one of the Companions of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was laid to rest. You will find a variety of shops where there is alot of buzz and hype. Locals are friendly and welcoming Be sure to visit

Beautiful. This mosque is like every other mosques in Turkey. Well designed and full of history signs. Also the grave of Ayub the Sahabi is here you can see it and if you're muslim you can make Duaa.Loved it

The Host of the Holy Prophet's tomb & the mosque. Most of the Muslims feel it their responsibility to pray at the tomb of Hazrat AbuAyub Ansari Raziallahanha, who is popularly known as the host of the holy prophet may peace be upon him. The Holy Prophet sallallahualaihe wasallam stayed at his home for the initial period of about six months at Hazrat AbuAyub Ansari's home. He was later sent as a Governor to Turkey & lived along life & was martyred himself fighting. His grave is here, which has been recently renovated. The tomb also has some of the things belonging to the Holy Prophet. There are also graves of some more companions in the nearby graveyard. The mosque has been built to accommodate a large number of people who come to say prayers specially on Friday. You will regret to miss, if you don't visit this place while in Istanbul.

A Spiritual Experience Coming from a Muslim. This place a different league of tourists. Mostly Muslims who come to pay tribute to Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari - a close companion of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). He was named after the biblical Job. Abu Ayyub was one among the Ansar meaning aiders, helpers or patrons, of early Muslim history or those who supported the Prophet after the migration to Medina in 622 (wikipedia). This is a spiritual journey, we were able to visit the mosque because it was my mother's wish. Took a cab from Basileus Hotel and arrived here in about 20-30 mins. The area has more serious, spiritual, typical muslim overtones with majority of the locals coming in from different parts of Turkey to pay their respects. There are prayer beads, prayer caps and prayer mats being sold everywhere. Someone or the other is always offering people sweetmeats because a child is born, or a child has passed exams or something similar. As a Muslim I always say yes and take a bite, why? I don't know. Tasty treats are being sold outside the mosque, corn cobs, fried potato chips. The mosque has an air of a certain type of calm. There is a huge, old tree in the middle having some significance but as the writings were all in Turkish and no available literature, we did not get to know the tree personally. Highly Recommended for both the religious or the not so religious.

Amazing architecture . Same as all fabulous mosques in turkey this one is amazing with its brilliant paintings on the walls and ceiling... A must visit, they also have a really nice market in the area with loads of stuff

Interesting History and Relics. It's best to take the tram to Kabatas and then the ferry to Eyup (and back). We took a taxi there (due to shortage of time) and almost got scammed big-time. Then took the ferry back to Kabatas after the cable car trip to and from Pierre Loti. It's a bit of a walk from the ferry stop to the mosque/cemetery and cable car station, but you pass some interesting shops on the way.

Important for Muslims, not so much for tourists. If you are traveling Istanbul as a non-Muslim tourist, this is a pleasant place to visit, but nothing that really stands out among the great mosques of the area. Good place to people-watch.

Beautiful mosque at the top of the Golden Horn. This is a beautiful smaller mosque at the top of the Golden Horn -- it's usually rather busy as it's also an important shrine for Moslems, but very well worth the trip, especially if you get there by using the ferry service up the Golden Horn from Eminonu.

Rich history and not as crowded as other tourist haunts.. Eyüp Sultan Mosque (“Camii”) is situated in the Eyüp district of Istanbul, outside the city walls near the Golden Horn (“Halic”). Ayub al-Ansari (Ayub = Eyup in Turkish), a companion and standard bearer of prophet Mohammed is buried in a tomb within the mosque grounds. The tomb was constructed five years after the Ottoman conquest of Constantinople in 1453. It was almost 800 years earlier when Eyüp Sultan died during the first siege of Constantinople in the 670s AD.Eyup Sultan Mosque, considered as the fourth most sacred mosque in the world after the mosques in Mecca, Medina and Jerusalem. Many tourists visit this site.Historically it has been Istanbul’s holiest site and was at one time the traditional site for the coronation ceremony of Ottoman Sultans, where new sultans were girded with the sword of Osman (Uthman) one of the Prophet's companions and the third caliph of Islam.
spiritual, religious place. A beautiful mosque with a great place all white just in front. The courtyard of the mosque is worth seeing as much as the inside of the building.
Beautiful mosque. The tomb of Abu Ayyub al-Ansarim, a close companion of Prophet Muhammad. I would highly recommended it for Muslims

Place of Serenity, Revival of Faith, Holy shrine of Muslim Ummah. It was a place of ultimate serenity. I'll suggest it to every Muslim visiting Istanbul. You'll catch the bus easily from Eminuno station. Pray for whole Muslim Ummah.

Spiritual journey. I came here as part of a family holiday in December 2015 - we came to pay our respects to Hazrat Ayub el Ansari (RA).
The mosque is beautiful and very well maintained, the resting place of Hazrat Ayub el Ansari was very busy with people flowing through constantly. The experience was amazing.
Excellent Trip. it was excellent trip to Istanbul with my family ,the weather was very nice and food excellent we visited a lot of places in Istanbul

A must visit for Muslims. The tomb of Hazrat Ayoub Ansari is a place not to be missed if you are in Istanbul. A special place for Muslims because Ayoub Ansari (RA) was a friend and companion of the Prophet Muhammad (SAW). Here i found it to be peaceful and spiritual. We visited on Fri morning and found many muslims in the tomb quietly reading Quranic verses. Such a lovely peaceful atmosphere.
Old beautiful Mosque. I loved this place as I went to Hill top with teleferic and then walked back to this mosque. Nice and beautiful place.

Spring Break Istanbul 2016. Eyup Mosque is a historical and religious site at the same time. Many Turkish locals regard it as holy ground. As a tourist you can see the high regard Muslims have for Ayub Ansar (RA). He is one of the original companions of he Prophet Mohammed (SA) buried outside of Middle East. It is good to read up on the history of his life and how they grave was found. You might see some types of worship that are questionable but as a visitor you have to respect the practices. Highly recommend taking a cab to this site as there is no tram that goes this far. It's a bit of a hike, but a must see for all Muslims and history lovers. There is a bazaar in the area and they sell all types of Muslim religious things. It can get crowded, plan your day accordingly.

Hazrat Eyup Ansari - host of Prophet SAW. Hazrat Abu Eyup (real name Khalid) Ansari R.A was the honorable citizen of Medinah and one of the earliest Medinese to accept Islam. When Prophet Muhammad ﷺ migrated to Medinah, he stayed at his house for few months. He had the honour of hosting Prophet ﷺ and was a prominent Sahaba (companion) of the Holy Prophet ﷺ . During the reign of Hazrat Muawiya he was part of the first expedition to Constantinople (although he was very old at that time). He felt ill during the course of the battle and left his will to the leader of Muslim army that he should be buried as close as possible to the walls of the city. The mosque and complex is the oldest in Istanbul. Sultan Mehmet Fatih ordered this after he conquered Constantinople and his sheikh (spritual leader) Ak Shamsuddin discovered the grave of Abu Eyup R.A. We planned to take ferry from Eminonu along the Golden Horn but when we reached Eminonu the last ferry had already left and the next one was in 50 mins time so we decided to catch bus 99A and it was quicker. Even before you have entered the actual mosque there is an amazing sense of tranquillity. The mosque architecture is impressive considering it was the first imperial mosque built by Ottomans. The tomb of Hazrat Abu Eyup is on one side from the main mosque. We went inside just before zuhur (mid day prayers) and paid our respect and salam to the great companion.

The Tomb of Abu Ayub Ansari. Eyup Sultan Mosque is built to next to the tomb of one of the companions of Prophet Mohammed, Abu Ayub Ansasi and who was a member of the first army sent by Amir Moayia under the leadership of Yarid to conquer Istanbul. Although this expedition was not successful, on his death, he was buried here as per his will. The site is worth a visit.

Beautiful mosque with excellent recitation. This mosque was by far my favourite in istanbul because it was busy with peaceful locals. The recitation during Maghrib prayer was so soothing that honestly gave me goosebumps Unfortunately it was a little far from the grand bazaar but it was well worth the travel. I wish I could visit this place again one day God willing

Place for muslim relegious people. Place and view is good. Since Eyup is muslim hero so this place is much better for them.
You can go to uphill by cable car and have coffee.
There is cheap market to buy regular stuff as well

Respect for the Companion of Prophet (saw). This is the first place we visited in Istanbul. Gave me feels of Madina (Saudi Arabia) thinking about the Abu Ayub Al Ansari.
MashaAllah very beautiful Masjid from inside and outside.The Ladies section was so calm and peaceful.

The tomb of Abu Ayub Al-Ansari. We visited this mosque for the sole reason of praying for the renowned disciple Abu Ayub Ansari. For getting here take bus no. 99/99A from Eminou towards Eyup Sultan, after ca. 15 minutes you'll arrive at your bus station. From here you can ask anyone about this mosque or use TripAdvisor map.

this beautiful site revisited . After our visit to pier loti we walked to the eyup sultan jamii. It is as grand as always. The squares and shops around it are lively and full of people.
There is a small shop thete specialised in maming hot sahlep drink, worth trying.

The tiles of mausoleum. The tiles of the wall of mausoleum is so beautiful and I was really glad to come here. There are many people visiting here, and there are many shops and cafe around the mosque. I just intended to drop by the mosque, but I looked around the shopping areas and had lunch at the cafe, so it was a half day trip from Sutalnahmet! Anyway, I cannot forget the beautiful spring day of Eyup.

Beautiful area, lovely place. The whole area with its mosque, square, graveyard, and the hill has a cozy relaxing feeling. This is the place where one of Prophet Muhammad's companions is buried. He accompanied the Muslim army in its quest to open Constantinople despite his old age(90's). He had asked to be buried at the place of his death, and was so.Highly recommended.9/10

Amazing Place. This is a very holy and special place for Muslim people. Eyup is the name of the Sultan which accommodated the prophet Mohammed in his own house.It's a great area with a beautiful mosque and much to see. The area has great restaurants and shops located around the mosque.

Family Trip. Must visit for all Muslims, tomb of Hazrat Abu Ayub Insari RA, very calm place compare to hassle and bustle of Istanbul main city, Non Muslim visitors should avoid prayer time, best time to visit is in morning upto 1pm, Very clean area massive bazaar as well, Good Shops to buy Islamic Books, Holy Quran, and souvenirs ... Bus ride is Long (40-50mins) from Sultanahmet area use tram T1 to Eminonu and use Ferry service (Goes every 30 min) you can use your Metro Card (will cost you 2.6 lira with card or 4 lira without) take ferry going from halic up to Eyup ... also another interesting thing around area is a cable car going up the hill, good views

The whole place has a special atmosphere. It's a very interesting part of Istambul, with the cemetary with interesting tombstones (it's fenced around) andt the Camii is interesting, the square with fountains and palms, and nearby old wooden houses and the Pierre Loti Cable Car. We loved the place.

Spiritual and Different. It's a beautiful mosque, but the real sight to see is the shine and Mohamed's footprint. To see these, you must join a queue starting on the outside part of the mosque. Remember to take off your shoes! People were dead silent inside - some of the greatest respect I've ever seen at a religious site. This place gets very crowded on the weekends, particularly on Fridays, so a weekday would be a better time to visit. The location is not easy to get to. There is no easy metro or tram access, though if you don't mind walking about 30-40min, the metro can get you there. You can also walk along the river from Eminonu, but this will take at least an hour.

A Spiritual Visit and Great Area (Eyup). We paid our respects at the shrine of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari who was a companion of our beloved prophet Muhammed (Peace Be Upon him).The mosque is very similar to the rest of the mosques in Istanbul in sense of the arcitecture etc; however the ambience is very heartly due to the blessed shrine on the grounds and the purpose of others visits.Despite Eyup being about 10 minutes out of the toursit filled Sultanahmet area it seemed as though we had entered another city as we got a true feel of the Turkish culture in this area.The people had been much more down to earth and even the shop keepers let you browse without the hassle.The prices of souvenirs, food etc are a fraction of what you pay in the Sultanahmet area and the prices quoted seem the initial genuine price as it would be for the locals.Whether you have a religious intent or not I would recommend a visit to Eyup Sultan Mosque and even the area around it to compare the difference between the rif raf of Sultanahmet.
Visit under the rain. Holly place due to one of profit Mohammad followers live and died there.The place is historic and tradition. We visited it during a beautiful rainy day

A place to visit for Muslim. A lot of Muslim come to visit The tomb of Prophet Muhammad's friend,Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari.I took bus 99A from Eminonu to this mosque.The mosque is very beautiful. you could also take a cable car nearby to Pierre Lotti Hill by using IstanbulKart or by walking.You could also do some shopping around the mosque and the price is very reasonable.

during the trip to perlotti resto. the spectacular detailed architecture of this mosque makes is unique. i had a visit to this place during a rainy day targetting perlotti cafe. unfortunately the cable cars were stopped due to weather conditions. there is a good market nearby the mosque where your can shop and enjoy the traditional turkish cuisine as well.
visit turkey. very beautiful place to see,we came from America, market shopping is good. but be careful for price ,need to negotiate, 100 liras ask for 50 or 60,no fix price

Most Sacred place in Istanbul. Shrine of the companion of last Prophet (P.B.U.H) is indeed the best place to visit, you can reach there by a 35 minutes Ferry ride of golden horn from Eminonu, or the bus from Eminonu.

A must-see and peaceful place to visit. A very beautiful mosque and the surrounding area ws very peacefull. This is also the place where the tomb of Hazrat Ayub Ansara (the Companion of the Prophet Muhammad PBUH) is loacted.We took a ferry from Eminonu to Eyub - you get off the fifth stop and as you get out of the Eyup ferry terminal just cross the road and you will see everyone walking towards the mosque.It was not that busy when we visted in December 2015 and you can spend as much time as you wish.Outside, the Eyup area is also very peaceful and you can buy things that are cheaper than other places.A really great place to visit.

Holiest Place. It looks like another mosque, but this is a special one. Very few tourists were there when I went - it was mostly locals. There are tombs in the area that you can visit as well, but check the hours/days of opening beforehand. There's a stand in front of the mosque selling sahlep which was yummy.

Very close to Pierre Loti. if you are going to visit Pierre Loti hill you may visit this historical very important mosque too..in the garden of this mosque there is a very big tree. if you like architecture you would like to visit there.

Average Place. Not a place to go "Specially". It is a mosque adjacent to tomb of Hazrat Abu Ayub Ansari, Companion of Holy Prophet Mohammad (PBUH). This i guess is only unique selling preposition of this mosque. Otherwise you may find many such mosques in Istanbul. However if you are visiting Piere Lottie, then it is just near to Chairlift point and one should visit it. There is a small market adjacent to it where you may find Turkish souvenirs.

sanctuary of istanbul. A Muslim tourist would find this mosque a must, a close companion of the Rasulullah was buried here. The man whose house was where he Prophet's camel stop at during his hijrah from Mecca to Madinah. His tomb is located behind the mosque.We took a boat from The Golden Horn ( 2liras one way) for a short ride across. Just follow the crowd.Shops ( food and other stuff) along the way. Many old tombs on the sides. Pigeons to feed. It can be crowded on weekends esp the morning prayers,so best go during weekday, during the regular prayer time to join the congregation. A bit of history revision may be beneficial.The historic mosque is beautiful and very peaceful.It was very quiet inside when we went there, despite the crowd at the tomb. A good place to rest and contemplate after one's journey.( Abu Ayub came to Turkey in those days already an old man) Ladies can go upstairs for solat/namaz. This mosque was specifically recommended by our host's boss, he was absolutely right.

So much peace and tranquility!. Come here early in the morning and have a breakfast at the top (pierre loti cafe), accessible by cable car and taxi.What a nice thing to do to start your day perfectly.

incredibly old. for a religion tourism, this mosque is one of the basic part of the tour. The story of it is very impressive and mosque is very old. It is very crowded especially at some important time of religion. must visit.
Mid Week Break. The Eyup area is full of history and historic buildings well worth hoping off the Big Red Bus here for a good look around you will be amazed at the sights.

Much cheaper than Taksim. Hey people, the bazaar beside the mosque is wonderful. you can find anything with prices cheaper than Taksim - even you can find the same products there. For shopping it is a must go.

EYUP EXCELLENT. Worth making the trek to see this particular attraction. ITs away from the touristy bits and is much more austere. The buildings and graveyards around it are fascinating. Take a bus from Eminonu.

Must visit this place. This is the tomb of one of Prophet Muhammad (may peace and blessings be upon him) companions Ayub Ansari RA.From Blue Mosque we paid 40 Lire to the Mosque/Tomb. Its quite an experience , try to go at night time or after sunset and enjoy the food there. There are atleast 6 open air restaurants with very nice turkish food.

A special, reverential holy site. Eyup Sultan Mosque is one of the four or five most holy sites in Islam depending on which source you research. It is a powerful and moving experience with Muslim pilgrims from all over the world in attendance and at prayer. Don't miss it if you can as it is a breathtaking experience.

Historic, istanbul. Quite the most spiritual, beautiful mosque that I have had the pleasure of visiting.lots of Moslems praying, very few tourists (I suppose it was out of season). My friend and I were so impressed that we visited it again a couple of days later. As is the Islam religion to give, we had many sweet meats and sugar lumps given to us - I went up to the women's praying section and again I was given a sweet - I'm sure it gave my diabetes no good at all!! It is just impolite to refuse.This complex also has a soup kitchen.
Nothing much to see, other than tombs. Did not enjoy the visit, only tombs of dead people. But the area has many restaurants and shops to buy souvenirs.

THE TOMB OF A GREAT SAHABI. The place is located at a considerable distance from Golden Horn, but I had ample time to walk over to the Great Man's tomb. It took me about and hour plus to reach the site. The tomb has its reverence, a great site links you back to the Muslim History. The man ABU AYUB ANSARI, whose house became the mainstay of our beloved Prophet Sallallao Alaiyeh e wassalam. The air is purely shrouded with respect. The will of the Sahabi be done as per his wish, and linked to this place today sleep in their deep eternal slumber are the graves of many which cover the mountain top which can be approached by foot or cable cars. May he stay among the blessed

Must visit for those interested in Islamic religious tours!. Beautiful mosque which also resides the tomb of one of the dearest sahaba companion of the Holy Prophet (SAW) - so you will many pilgrims visiting his tomb which is greatly venerated.There are shops nearby with good choice of tourist items (usually cheaper than the SultanAhmet area).

Must Visit . It is a great place. One of the shabah( companion of the Holy Prophet(PBUH) is buried there. A must visit. Apart from that the shops around the area are about 40% less costly than the Sultanhemet area.

Favourite Mosque in Istanbul. Personally, this is my favourite mosque in Istanbul. It is sooo beautiful and peaceful. The whole Eyub Sultan area is a peaceful retreat from hectic Sultanahmet area. So bright and vibrant, full of local people. The tomb of the Prophet Pbuh's companion, Abu Ayub al Ansari is so special, tranquil and a memory I'll hold close to my heart forever. There is also an alcove in the wall of the tomb containing items belonging to Prophet Muhammed Pbuh. Very special. A must see when in Istanbul!
Great Mosque. Is a visit to this mosque a must? No, not really, BUT, I personally enjoyed it, as there were no tourist, which gave me the opportunity to sit and enjoy this masterpiece.@instabuilt

Eyup Sultan Area. This is so nice and beautiful place which you will enjoy the coffee shops and the restaurants around you. Get the telefric to the top of Eyup place to enjoy the turkish coffee as well as to get a nice view of istanbul from the top. also Eyup mosque is a beautiful deserve to visit it and the fountain at the front of the mosque its so nice i prefer to go in the morning.

Great Spiritual Place. The Eyup Sultan place was very special to me. It is very lovely and beautiful. It has the flavor of Old Istanbul. As for the mosque, the atmosphere is very peaceful. There is something so attractive about this place. I highly recommend a visit. You are going to fall in love with it. I did :)

Amazing spiritual place with a quaint flavour of old Istanbul. This is a revered Muslim site of spiritual significance. The Mosque is lined by market stalls, tea gardens, home-style restaurants, bakeries, sweet shops and nurseries. I highly recommend a visit.

Great. Excellent bus ride from Sultan Ahmed area .About 15 min .Lovely fountains in adjoining area.The mosque was great and the tomb of one of the companions of the Holy Prophet (pbuh) was peaceful and atmosphere was tranquil.A must visit for every devout a Muslim.

Cemetery and Pierre Loti. I love to take a walk in Eyup cemetery. Both the views of Istanbul it affords and the cemetery itself are very special to me. As is the boat ride to Eyup, all the way up the Golden Horn. A well spent couple of hours. Eyup Sultan Mosque was erected over Prophet Mohammad's companion resting place.
Nice place. , Amazing historic place to visit , reflect the real Turkish life style I liked the Bazar nearby, I liked the simple restaurants also there

The Heart of Locals. If tou want to see the real Turkish locals pay a visit to Eyüp Sultan camii, I would highly recommend taking a ferry from Eminönö through the golden horn kiosk, you would love the experience, the mosque in about 2 minutes walk for the port, have a round at this religious neighbourhood then enter the camii, its so peaceful and nice i went with my friend we both enjoyed it so much.

One of the oldest mosques. A great mosque where it is said that lies the tomb of Eyup, a friend of the Prophet who fell in battle outside the walls of Constantinople. Moreover, the mosque was the place where used to take place the coronation ceremony for the Ottoman princes. A place of great significance for the Muslims.
Great place for Friday prayers. Great atmosphere for prayers, and to view the tomb of Eyup Ansari, supposedly one of the companions of Prophet Mohammed, PBUH.
spiritual place for Muslims. spiritual place for Muslims , I loved the place enjoyed the Mosque environment and the Holy Quran reading at the time after prayers .
Traditional and authentic. One of the traditional mosque with authentic ambiance. Rustic yet comfortable. Sharing boundary with the bazaar.
Watch Istanbul from above. SO beautiful district so holy mosque and grave of Eyub the friend of prophet Mohamad. Cheap shopping around.Then you walk to the amazing Pierre lotti Cafe.
Old historical building. Amazing.. We went there in April 2014. No words can describe how beautiful and authentic this old mosque

Wonderfull and very special. One os the most sacred sites of Istanbul. it has wonderful tile clawing and very accessible by public transportation and ferries. It is also a stepson to the Pierre Loti Hill and Coffee shop via Telefric.

The Standard-bearer and Friend of Islamic Prophet Muhammad Buried Here.. The Eyup Sultan Mosque is located just outside the city walls of Istanbul, near the Golden Horn. Eyüp (Job) al-Ansari, the standard-bearer and friend of the Islamic prophet Muhammad, is said to have been buried here. Eyüp Sultan's tomb is greatly venerated by Muslims, attracting many pilgrims from all over the world every year. The tomb is well worth a visit while you are visiting the mosque. It has some very beautiful cool tiles on the wall too so don't miss it. Here's how to find the tomb: The mausoleum is on the north side of a courtyard opposite the main entrance to the prayer hall of the mosque.

Aashiq-eRasool(saw). Been wishing to ziyaarat this place after watching Islamic documentry on TV. Subhanallah,
I wish to pay my visit again & again

Go on a Friday. Best time to go is Friday when the whole Muslim world of Istanbul congregate. As a foreigner go earlier on your way back from the Pierre Loti cafe. There are lots of interesting trinket shops and bonets (headdress) to buy even for non Muslims. A bit like Tinos or Lourdes for religious 'souvenirs' priced for 'the people' not for the tourists! Separate entrances for men and women. Highly recommended. Quite an experience. Take your camera.

A very spiritual experience. We visited tomb of Ayub Al Ansari. He was standard bearer to Prophet Muhammad pbuh. When the Prophet and his companions were expelled from Mecca and went to Madina many locals invited him to stay with them. So not to offend anyone the Prophet said that he would stay at the house where is camel would stop. The camel stopped at the house of Ayub Al Ansari. He showed great hospitality and insisted that who ever came to visit the prophet could not leave without taking food and drink. He was a brave warrior and was the first to volunteer when he was needed. On the campaign to defeat the Byzantine Empire by this time he was an old man He fell ill, It was his dying wish that he be buried under the walls of Constantinople. So this is very holy site for Muslims. The area is now known as Eyup Sultan. There is a lovely mosque and nice restaurants and some good souvenir shops also they are cheaper than the touristy parts.

Amazing area. Loved the place and the area around it. the market is much cheaper that other areas in istanbul, like Sultanahmet and others.. and the ride to Pierre Lotti and the time spent there was well wroth the trip :)

Stunning History, but sometimes very crowded. This Camii (or Mosque) is sometimes referred to as the fourth most holy site for Muslims and it is an amazing cultural experience as well.Located outside of the history city walls, this location is the site of the remains of Eyup who was a flag bearer for the Prophet Mohammed. Because of this history, it draws many people throughout the Islamic world to come and visit. There is a beautiful plaza with lots of outdoor treats like Majun (lolipops, but the experience is cool), Popcorn and Cotton Candy. There will often be events hosted in the beautiful little neighborhood that is set apart from the rest of Istanbul, and if you are a history buff, there are plenty of sites around this location that you can see.If you are around here during Ramadan, Eyup boasts one of the greatest places to hold Iftar, a large grassy square off of the main road where hundreds of families gather to break their fast. Pull up a blanket and prepare some food (store bought or home made) and you are sure to make a lot of friends.
Eyup Sultan. The Mosque of Eyup Sultan is one of the holiest Islamic Shrines as Eyup was the standard bearer of the Holy Prophet Mohammed.

Wow!!! . Me and my husband visited eyup sultan mosque after going on the cable cars. This mosque is beautiful the architecture is just amazing and if ur a cat lover its like kitty galore round here loved it. Its such a peaceful place to be just relax and enjoy the moment. This mosque has 2 floors the woman pray upstairs and the men downstairs. The spiral stairs going up was just beautiful love the old kinda historic staircases just bricks. But i couldnt go back down them im guessing for safety reasons as it was very narrow and steep. Theres lots of shops out side the mosque me and my hubby even got yummy ice creams for 1 turkish lira cant go wrong. A great place to visit. They also have the graves of the sahabas their. I loved this place.
Worth a visit. So impressive to discover such a splendor. The mosque opens up to the mausoleum where the Prophet Mohamed companion Abi Ayub Al Ansari is buried

If your in town for a few days,this is a must. After the main attractions of the town this is good trip. the fourth most holy mosque in the world it sits at the very end of the golden horn and is best reached by the excellent public water bus service (2tl per person) the mosque and burial grounds are the main attraction but there are lots of shops(serving mostly Turkish tourists) and a cable car up to a cafe with great views back down the golden horn to the city) (must be the cheapest cable car in the world at 2 tl (20p UK) ) A good tip is to use this trip to stop of a couple of stops before Eyup to visit the fantastic industrial museum you will see from the boat of the right side of the horn)
beautiful view of the city istanbul and water. we got there by teleferik ( can be found in subway map). beautiful view of the city istanbul and water.

Good for peopleewatching & the scene, mosque not for tourists. Not a destination for non-Muslim tourists, but lots of local pilgrims. Good people watching. Well off the tourist path. Return to Old City via ferry for a fun 30 minute view of Istanbul from the water.

So crowded but worth to see.. Because of its importance in religion history, we wanted to visit it too. The only negative thing about this mosque, muslims who visited the place they were little bit lack of understanding and agressive. But the place was peaceful and it worth to go and see.

Most underrated site in Istanbul. Go on a Friday and plan your trip to have lunch on the second floor of one of the delicious Turkish restaurants surrounding the Mosque- they are all very cheap and excellent quality. Watching the prayers was one of the most special experiences that we had in Istanbul. You can spend the early morning at the Chora Church and then walk down to the Ferry and take a boat to this area. It was a special day.

Eyup Sultan. a must see place, the eyup sultan grave he was buried here and many of his students as well, there is shops restaurants and souvenirs for tourist all around the mosque, toilets is for extra charge

One of the holiest sites in Istanbul. Easily accessed by bus from Eminonu bus station, this mosque is the last resting place of one of the Prophet's key lieutenants and also contains a stone that bears the imprint of one of the Prophet's feet as well as some very early calligraphy.The tomb of Eyup Ensari is the main focus of interest and although it is always crowded by pilgrims we were made very welcome there and through them we discovered the significance of the artefacts and the piece of marble. The silver railings that conceal the tomb were very beautiful but although we love Iznik tiles there were so many in this small crowded place that it was almost overwhelming.After the tomb the mosque itself is quite a contrast but also very beautiful in its own way as is the surrounding area
Amazing vies. We took a taxi from the church of ChoraWe could not find the graves of the Sultans but views are amazing We took the cable car down
A holy place. This is a place where the great companion of the Prophet is buried. Place full of spirituality and faith. Here you may see many locals visit the place to receive blessings.

Most holy mosque in Istanbul. Eyup is a historical district in Istanbul. The mosque is maybe not grand as Blue mosque, Suleymaniye or Saint Sophia neverthless it is considered the most holy mosque among Muslims. After visiting the mosque, you can take the telecabin and have a break at Pierre Loti.
Serene. Amazing architecture and wonderful details. Organized, clean and calm. Lively area with many shops and food places around the mosque itself and easily reached by bus.

View the complex as a whole - not just the mosque.. This mosque, and particularly the surrounding complex is certainly worth a visit, and seemed to be visited mostly by what looked like pilgrims - not many westerners seemed to make the very worthwhile effort. The complex is also very convenient if you want to go up Pierre Loti hill on the cable car - very close by. And Eyup jetty is there for a pleasant boat trip back to the main areas of the old city.

Place of Islamic importance. Apparently the first mosque in Istanbul by no other than Ayub Ansari ra. It is an untouched gem, which is well used by locals and is surrounded by other sites to warrant a day visit I.e. local market stalls, Pierre Lotti Cafe, a funfair by the water, telegraphic cars and of course the tomb of Ayub Ansari. Tombs of other sahabas are also nearby. We wanted to go on a Islamic tour with Harun from Meriva Travel, but didn't have time unfortunately. Maybe next time!
a very holy place of peace. a place of worship for the people that understand the true significance of the religion of Islam and to visit the grave of one of the Prophet Muhamed closest friends.

Spiritual place. Beautiful mosque. Good for food. I had dinner there and it was hard for me to choose as there are so many restaurant there. Foods seems to me the same but the restaurant I chose was an open air restaurant close the main fountain was a bit pricey. But otherwise really beautiful location. Do not forget to pay tribute to Abu-Ayub Ansari (RA) shrine.

Interesting and plenty of locals around. Nice mosque and very interesting area, especially if you want to see more local or Turkish people and less tourists. It is highly recommended to go to the Eyup cementery and then go down by foot. Go back to Sultanhammet or Galata by ferry,you'll enjoy it!

A must for those who are interested.. Not necessarily one on the tourist trial but important to those trying to get under the surface of the Ottoman history. For those of the religious persuasion a chance to visit the grave and final resting place of a companion of the Prophet Muhammad, saws.

Wonderful Islamic History. For Muslims, a spiritual place where they can pay their respect to one of Prophet Mohammad's SAW companions, whose tomb lies here. A short ferry hop from the main tourist area, then cross the road and it is a two minute walk. You can also buy some wonderful potato fritters on a stick outside the entrance. How they make those is impressive.

An authentic sacred place for the Muslims. The mosque and the sorrounding complex is very crowded by pilgrims, and you feel like in a living sacred place, not a tourist attraction. So as a tourist you are not encouraged to go around. The place is a bit dirty and suffocating, still it is fashinating and "real".

A place must be visited. Went there with my family, initially we had no idea that one of the close companions of prophet Muhammad (P.B.U.H) was buried here, before the day of arrival we read up the details which filled our hearts with joy. we we reached the tomb, the atmosphere was so exhilarating and took us back in time. I realised that there were many other companions of prophet Muhammad (P.B.U.H) also buried there who came to conquer Istanbul during the first campaign. the square round the place is buzzing with activity and one can find many shops to taste local savouries and delights. must not miss the fresh orange juice from the corner cart, feeding the pegions and having the turkish tea.

Peaceful & touching . My mum had been to Istanbul 6 months before I went, so she told us to not miss the opportunity to visit this beautiful Mosque.We took a taxi from our hotel in Sultanahmet. The taxi cost us only 20liras, which was good because the cabby was to meet us after sometime to take us to our next destination.It was a very spiritual day with a lot to take in.It is a very peaceful place and a must see while in Istanbul.
Charming mosque. A bautiful octagonal structure, situated further away in Eyup, with interesting tile work in the interior.

Ancient Mosque and mausoleum. Another historical mosque of many in turkey. This mosque is also a very spiritual place for alot of people as well as locals. Situated are here are graves of important islamic figure most of them is hazrat Ayub, One of the companions of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him)

Superb. I like it to the max very peaceful and relaxing place
We took the bus from eminunu station bus A99
there's many restaurants nearby and some traditional shops.
At least there's no queue we can enter directly

The most important mosque in Istanbul for Muslims. There is very little mentioned about this mosque in the West because the mosque is not as grand as other mosques in the city but this mosque is a gem. Its atmosphere is amazing because it contains the grave of the Companion of Prophet Muhammad (SAW) - Ayub Ansari RA in the complex and hence its the most important and busiest mosque in Istanbul for Muslims. Make sure you come here for Friday prayers if you are muslim as the atmosphere is amazing. The outside of the mosque gets laid out with mats because there is not enough space within the mosque to accommodate everybody.

Beautiful Eyub Sultan Cami. Beautiful mosque,rich in history. The main attraction was the Mausoleum of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari, he was a companion of Prophet Muhammad who passed away In Istanbul.Great place to visit for those who appreciate history and architecture

EYUP SULTAN MOSQUE. A wow at every sight, very good architecture a delight of history from the ottoman empire days. this place is a must to visit whilst travelling around istanbul. cant wait to visit again.
Eyup Sultan Mosque. you will surprise if you know that Eyup Sultan was not real Sultan just a very respective man from Islamic history

Definitely worth a visit.. Eyup itself is brilliant. We took a boat from Istanbul for 3L and found the area to be really interesting (and much cheaper than Istanbul) The Mosque is great to look at architecturally although we couldn't find much information around us and were glad of hang done our research beforehand to really get the most out of it.

Muslims spiritual . This is the place of one of great prohfet mohammad (PBUH ) Abu ayub Ansari tomb it's sacred place to Muslims and especially the turkish the mosque and tomb located walking distance from pierrerloti cafe in the golden horn easily reached by bus, ferry from eminonu you need half day visit to start at euyp have spiritual feeling and wonder in one of most classical ottoman design and learn more about Muslim you finish your visit by having a turkish cafe at pierrerloti and enjoying the stunning view of the golden horn. Must visit Mahmoud Yamani
Breathtaking. Amazing area with amazing architecture from Ottoman Empire times of İstanbul. Never say I'm done in this city. In each district, you will see some amazing stuff for sure.

An inspirational shrine. Mosque adjoins tomb (shrine) of the Companion of Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) Hazrat Abu Ayub Ansari (ra). An inspirational place for Muslims with a great sense of calmness and serene. Take a bus No. 99A from Eminanu to Ayup Sultan and you will be there in 20 minutes.

nice to see the local daily life. The place is very sacred to the locals, and usually you don't see tourist around. The mosque is nice and it has the grave of Ayub AlAnsari. If you would like to live like a local in Istanbul I strongly recommend you visit the area, where you will have chance also to taste from the local bakeries and buy local grocery and the best place to take the cable car to Pierri Lotte which is high peak overlooking the Golden Horn, one of the best view in Istanbul and have a cup of Turkish tea or coffee there.

A peaceful atmosphere and beautiful mosque. The Eyup Sultan Mosque is a very sacred place to Muslims, so dress respectfully and try not to act too touristy. It's a beautiful mosque, and you feel the reverent atmosphere more so than other mosques in Istanbul. The square outside is paved with marble. It is also conveniently near the cable cars that take you up to Pierre Loti.

AMAZING SPIRITUAL PLACE TO VISIT. Definitely a highlight and a MUST visit for MUSLIM families and visitors. Simply beautiful and very welcoming to all - a must visit. Great architectural features and amazing to witness prayers there. Very lively local area with many shops and restaurants also. MUST visit A.Y.S. TATLICILIK about a 10 minute walk , small dessert shop - the MOST AMAZING turksih dessert called TIRLECE in Turkish (three milk dessert).

Holy Site. A very holy site for Muslims who go there to pay homage to Ayub Ansari who lies buried there. Ayub was a companion of the Holy Prophet. A public bus or ferry from Eminino will transport you to this site. After walking through the bazaar area you come to a beautiful fountain from where you enter the holy complex. There is a mosque but most visitors focus and the tomb of Ayub which is situated in the courtyard adjacent to the mosque. It has a serene atphosphere and is usually crowded with pilgrims. You are not allowed inside the Dargah but restricted to the lattice and glass window from where you can deliver your prayers or as some believe that it is the place where wishes and prayers made will come true. When leaving you may see young boys dressed as little sultans, some even mounted on horses. These youngsters are initiates by virtue of circumcision. For those interested the place is surrounded by several other tombs of holy personages.

Nice Neighboorhood with Golden Horn View. Eyup area is really crowded during weekend, however every weekend there are various exhibition in the Halic that you can simply go for free. Then, take an additional visit to Pierre Loti using cable car (Teleferik) to view the fascinating Golden Horn Area
Must visit. The resting place of the companion ayub ansari. If you are in Istanbul visiting Eyup is a must. If you have time take a ship to eyup from eminuni

respect. this is not an avg tourist place. its a very sacred place. i was a little turned off because ppl were treating it like a amusement park of sorts.please when you visit such places turn off the tourist mode and have the respect mode on. say you salam, pray and leave quietly. you will have plenty of other picturesque places for selfies!

A must visit for its history. We visit the grave of Eyup Al-ansar a sahabat of Rasulullah s.a.w and its a great opportunity that we glad to take as it has an extensive Islamic history. It is an emotional visit for us.

its one of the best for muslims but also for tourists. on our way to the famous hill and cafe ...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seven_hills_of_Istanbulwe passed by the mosque and went inside..it was the praying moment and the tourists cant enter inside.but we had a look in surrounding area and mosque.

Amazing place. You have to go here just to see the Shrine of Abu Ayyub Al Ansari. It was totally amazing when we went. We went on Eid and there were 1000s of Turks there and in the bazaars surrounding it. If you are in Istanbul, you have to visit this place, even if you are non muslim.The mosque was full of sufis at prayer time, and even though there were so many people, it was a very spiritual visit. You may see children all dressed in white which is their way of celebrating they have been circumcised.The fastest way to get there is to take the 99a bus from Eminonu. If you are not sure just asked the driver 'Sultan Eyup?' and you should get a response.If you are you, you have to go up to Pierre Loti which is on the other side of the complex. There is a 5 minutes cable care (telefrik) that gets you there....and it is high up. The views are amazing.Buy the IstanbulKart which will cover all your public transportation expenses and then some. One card can be used for many people. Just top it up and go.....its very cheap....taxis can be expensive.Enjoy!!
A lot of history. This place has islamic history, go on a sunday and you will see young boys dressed up. nice restaurants around the mosque to eat.

Peaceful and Spiritual Visit. The Eyüp Sultan Mosque (masjid) is in the Eyüp district in Istanbul, I went easily by Bus 55T from Taxim Square.It was the first Mosque constructed by the Ottoman Turks in Istanbul in 1458 and was the traditional site for the coronation ceremony of the Ottoman Sultans, where the new sultan was girded with the sword of Osman. The mosque had been re-built after destroyed by an earthquake. The mosque includes a mausoleum where Eyüp al-Ansari, one of Sahabah (bearer and companion) of the Islamic prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him), is said to be buried (it was under restoration, closed). A grave yard lie in the proximity of Ayyub al Ansar’s Tomb where it was also a very honorable situation to be buried there. You feel peace and safety once you enter the mosque. it's wonderful architecture appear in the pillars, mehrab and domes with amazing colors and light reflections. the mosque is surrounded by many bazaars selling Turkish products and restaurants ... You must visit it .... make it in the morning to avoid crowed.

Gem if istanbul. If you intend to go to Pierre Loti, you should stop at Eyup sultan mosque. Named after companion of prophet Muhammed,mosque is frequently visited by worshipers. For morning prayer it has thousands of people. It is surrounded with cemetary that include graves of greatest military leaders of Ottoman empire. You can walk up thru the cemeteries to rhe Pierre Lotti. It takes 10 minutes (once you are above mosque just keep left on the paths)

Authentic place specially on sunday. Is one of the areas that we liked most. We arrive by ferry and the atmosphere was spectacular. Full of small children dressed as sultans with families. An area full of life away from the tourist crowds .

Well worth a visit. We caught a ferry from Eminonu, just past the bus staion. The ferry took apporx 20mins during which time you coauld have tea/coffee etc served. The ferrry on it's own was a nice experience, the ticket seller at the pier came out of his office to dry the seats for us to wait for the boat, I couldn't see this happening at home. We walked from the ferry port at Eyup to the mosque browsing at various stalls selling prayer beads, towels and various different items. The mosque sits behind a beautiful fountain, it is one of the nicest mosques to visit and a lot less touristy than the Blue mosque. I would recommend bringing sunglasses as the the glare from the marble in front of the mosque is sore on the eyes.We spent the day in the area around the mosque eating, shopping and admiring the fruit trees in a local garden centre. All in all one of the best days in Istanbul

A moving experience. From the perspective of being a muslim, this was a moving experience to visit the mosque and the mausoleum of this great companion of the Prophet Muhammed (PBUH).This place is located just within walking distance of the "Telephonic" (cable care the goes from the Eyup Sultan area up to Pierreluti). One can offer fatihah at the resting place. There was quran being recited in the background, which was moving.There are many place around this area where one can eat as well.

Eyup Sultan Parc during Ramadan. Me and my girlfriend got a tip to visit This Area in Istanbul during Ramadan.It was one of the best sights in Istanbul!!!We were instructed people start eating around 20.50 so we arrived at 19.00 at this area.There were thousands of people, families, Couples, Young and old...well a great variety of people.There are a lot of traditional restaurants, and in the parc area thera are many stablishment that offers fixed dinners.Most people bring food and drinks and spend hours on blankets in the grass. It was a great feeling of friendship and tranquility in the parc which was crowded for many hours.We left at eleven and were told people stayed until 03-0500 in th morning to eat more before sunrise.A really great experience!!!

Conservative area, beautiful marble. We saw the Mosque as we walked the area. A very beautiful area and Mosque. This seems to be a more conservative area- more a tourist site for Muslims- did not see many Americans. We decided to not go inside- we were headed to the Loti cafe and also not sure we were dressed correctly.
Go on Sunday. It is a very especial place . Go before to the Pierre Loti Café and reach the Mosque through the cemetery.If you go on Sunday, you will see the boys wearing ceremony suits.

make it your first place to visit. This place holds the grave of Abu Eyup Al Ansari. The grave and the mosque are very beautiful and worth multiple visits. The area is surrounded by markets that offers cheaper prices than other places in Istanbul.
Spiritual Must visit for Muslims. A sure must visit site for Muslims. The tomb of Hazrat Ayub Ansari R.A. is placed here. You get a lot of mental peace and perspective.

My first mosque visited in Istanbul . This one struck me better than what a rustompasha did..or a blue mosque despite its beauty over this. Maybe coz.this was my first structure visited and created it's impact. Traveller here through the golden horn bosphorus cruise ride..what made it more enjoyable was the walk to iy..with several souvenir kiosks on one side. .a Pierre loti cablecar ride before it..the Graves in pretty trellises...a lovely shopping street with several things to discover and a square to rest by and watch the world go by..not to forget the bosphorus right opposite the street.Plus the blue tiles inside and views through its trellised laced walls was charming..got many beautiful photos. .Must stop and discover all of this. .

Beautiful and spiritual. The visit to the Eyup Sultan Mosque was truly an amazing experience, it's a great place for the whole family (keep in mind that it is also a religious place so respect to the venue and the people there is of the utmost importance), it also houses the tomb of Eyüp al-Ansari (standard bearer and friend of Mohammed PBUH) so it's a there will be a lot of devotees. The place is also at foot of the Pierre Lotti Cemetry and garden where one can enjoy the spectacular view of the Golden Horn and Bosphorus while having a cup of cay and a curly fried potato. the place has an abundance of cafeterias and restaurants and is a 5 minutes walk away from an expo center which frequently hosts cultural and artistic fairs from all parts of Turkey. So visit the place, don't rush things (let yourself absorb the beauty and peace of the location) and you'll be in for a great day.

if you are interested with religious side of turkish people. the district is not close to the historic center..you have to go outside the roman walls.but if you would like to see lots of turkish or arabic or muslim people praying , showing respect to the dead people , this is really an authentic place..especially during the midday praying each friday.after visiting the mosque , pls do not forget to take the funicular to go uphill and get one of the best views of the town.and feel close to the house and spirit of Pierre Loti(Julien Viaud)..famous french writer who fell in love with the ottoman girl aziyade and stayed there/here...

Unique beauty. LOCATION OF THE MOSQUEEyup Mosque is located in Eyup quarter of Istanbul. Orhan Pamuk, the famous writer, wrote about this quarter as a little and a perfect village located at the end of the Golden Horn, that does not look realistic, but it always seems as semblance. HOW TO GET TO THE MOSQUEIf you take taxi drive from the Sultan Ahmet square /the Old Town/ or Taksim to Eyup quarter, it will cost about 30-40 TUR LIR or 10-12 EUR. Make a deal with a driver in advance. THE MOSQUE ITSELFThe ground plan is a rectangle. The dome sits on a cylinder which rests on eight semi-domes. The domed hall is surrounded by tree-sided balcony. The biggest attraction of the mosque represents the tiles that decorated the inner and outer walls of the mosque. They are the most beautiful examples of Iznik ceramics (16th-19th century). As an art lover, I could not take my eyes off these so beautiful tiles and I took many great photos of them. Next to the mosque, there is a fabulous fountain, that is one more spot for photo-stop. Only rule is: cover your hair /for women/ and cover your shoulders and knees /for everybody/ when you go in the mosque. RECOMMENDATIONThe beautiful decoration of the mosque deserves your attention and admiration. After visit of the mosque, take a walk along Eyup quarter's cobblestone that recalls some past centuries. You will feel as if you are taken to some other centuries and captured in the charm of old times. You will find both artistic beauty of the Eyup mosque and old charm of Eyup quarter. Warm recommendation!

super. Eyup sultan is the burial location of abu ayyub al ansari (R) the neighbour and friend of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him.) When he was dying, he asked that his friends but his body on a horse and attack as far as they could and bury him deep within enemy territory. This they did and centuries later, the army of Mehmet Faith (the conqueror of Constantinople) found his grave and built the mausoleum and mosque at the site.

The Islamic spiritual center of Istanbul. Eyup Sultan Mosque ,Sahaba Eba Eyyub Al Ansari- one of the companions of prophet Mohammed (peace be upon him ) has been the Islamic spirutal center of Istanbul for centuries. Eyyub Ansari joined to Arabic army to conquer Constantinople in 7th century AD but he was matryed in front of the city walls during the siege. When Constantinople was conquered by Mehmet II in 1453, the name was turned into Islambol-the city of the muslims- and Sultan's teacher called Aksemseddin found his tomb later. Sultan ordered to build a monumental shrine on the former toms place with a beautiful mosque. Ottoman sultans paid a great respect to Eyyub Ansari's shrine and most of them were crowned in Eyup Sultan. Visiting the shrine and praying in the mosque became a tradition not only by the Royal family and the inhabitants of Istanbul visited both places in religous festivals, pregnant ladies came here to have a healthy babies, young girls visited his shrine to find their future husbands, little boys were circunsized here and so on for thousands of years. Therefore the district was protected by the Ottoman government for a long time. On the other hand, both members of Ottoman dynasty & high officials and ordinary citizens wanted to be buried near Eyyup Sultan shrine as to be forgiven by Allah on behalf of prophet's companion. Therefore a big cemetery has been formed for centuries. Eyup discrict is a big open air cemetery museum containing with thousands of gravestones, shrines and tombs from 1453 to 1990. Ottoman history can be searched by looking at the beautiful written inscriptions in Eyup and it is a real " open air gravestone museum " today. The shrine and the mosque are always crowded and he makes a great contibution to the city's economy even today. It is a good example for " sacred & holy tourism industry " for Muslim world.

A beautiful madjid.. Eyup sultan jamii as they call it in Turkey is a mosque complex hosting the tomb of Prophet Mohammed's Apostle (Abu Eyup AlAnsari).That's why it is a very popular place in Turkey that receives thousands of worshippers all year round.Beside it is an old shopping area full of restaurants and shops.The place is buzzing with life but also has a tranquil aura to it.A beautiful experience not to be missed by any Istanbul visitor.

The Most Sacred Mosque in Istanbul. I visited this mosque twice in different trips to Istanbul. It's the first mosque that was built by Ottomans, and has the tomb of (Abu Ayub Al-Ansari), one of the Prophet Muhammad's companions, who was buried there after his participation in the first siege of Constantinople by Muslims.At the area, you'll find many locals walking around, less tourists than Sultanahmet area, of course. Try to walk around and try the small shops nearby for cheaper souvenirs. Don't miss taking the cable car (Telefrik) from Eyup area to Pieri Lotti Cafe, with its sensational panoramic view on the Golden Horn.

The very special place for Muslim people and must be very interesting to everybody.. In Feb. 2015 I had a chance to visit the famous and respectable Eyup Sultan Mosque. The Mosque and the district have the religious spirit and the oriental atmosphere. It’s the 4th place in the world for Muslims after Mecca, Medina and Jerusalem. There is a tomb of Eyup el-Ensary there and the grounds considered sacred. He was the companion of the Prophet Mohammed. In the VIIth century Eyup died during the siege of Constantinople by Arabs. The mosque was built by 1458 by the order of Sultan Mehmed II Fatih after he had conquered Constantinople from the Byzantine Empire in 1453. Later on in the Middle Ages, Eyup Sultan Mosque became a very important point for all the sultans of the Ottoman Empire-they have passed there the procedure of the Osman Sword girding-a ritual a bit similar to the coronation of the European kings-after which the sultan received the full power. After all, it’s simply another Istanbul! The charm of this outstanding spot has the long history and conserved well till our times. The ancient cemeteries surrounding the mosque add the Medieval air to this old and well established district. Numerous pilgrims and tourists come to this area, full of peace and beauty of the past. Moreover, you can also get to the famous and romantic Pierre Loti Café on the top of the hill, close to the Eyup Sultan Mosque. The panorama of Istanbul which opens from there is just breathtaking! Recommended!!!

Because of this, it became a popular burial place for Sultans, and also the place where the Sultans were invested in the ceremony of putting on the sword. For non-Muslims, the tombs are interesting but not particularly special and the mosque itself is pleasant but not exceptional.

See the tomb of the Prophet's flag-bearer. I enjoyed the tranquil atmosphere in this mosque between prayer times. Men and women are not segregated and children scamper quietly. Take some time to sit quietly and reflect.

A very special place. I first visited Eyup SUltan Mosque in September 2013. They were filming a historic drama at the time so did not stay for long before going on to Pierre Loti Cafe. There was an elderly gentleman sitting outside the mosque with a small box of assorted perfume oils and he was perfuming the right hand of every person entering the mosque. (he did not accept any payment and was doing this as an act of devotion). I visited again in October 2014 just after the Eid and the place was full of pilgrims. I stayed for longer this time and enjoyed the definate 'spiritually special' atmosphere of this holy place. People were giving gifts to visitors as acts of charity and I was presented with a pair of socks by a young woman as I sat in the mosque courtyard which I accepted although I have yet to wear them! This tradition is observed usually when a person has had a prayer answered or it is done in memory of a loved one.Eyup Sultan Mosque now certainly occupies a special place in my heart and I just have to recollect my visit to again experience the calm serenity of the place despite it being very busy. The old man with the perfume was not there this time and I missed him, perhaps he will be there the next time I visit.

If you want to experience a true Muslim Istanbul, then this is the place to go.The surrounding area is beatiful and more real. And things are much cheaper here. Near the mosque is also tomb (türbe) of Sokollu Mehmed Pasha, Grand Vizir and de facto ruler of the Ottoman Empire under three sultans – Suleiman the Magnificent, his son Selim the Sod and Murad III.
