A must when in Istanbul. This is my second visit to Eyup Sultan Mosque and the surrounding area. Very nice historic place. I like shopping for souvineres where they are much cheaper. We prayed at the mosque, went by the cable car up (Pier Lotti Cafe with awasome views). Then, we had lunch in one of the restaurants facing the mosque. Very nice day.
Visit during Eid el Adha. This is a very local mosque and busy as our visit was during Eid el Adha. It is a site of pilgrimage for Muslims and contrasted well with the more well known mosques.

A beautiful place with welcoming people. As a Muslim, it was an honour to visit the grave of Abu Ayyub al-Ansari (R.A). I found the whole place very special, and spiritually very enlightening. The surrounding area is good for shopping for Islamic items, including Quran's and Islamic attire.

other mistic station. I have to be honest my expectation was very high because I have been to Saint SOPHIA (Ayasofya) , Eyüp Sultan of course beautiful but I like Saint Sopahia more .
Also Eyüp Sultan was very very crowded .
Great Mosque in a great area. Very interesting mosque , it is a little bit far from the city center , but situated in a nice environement on the golden horn

Good area. It is a nice area to be around. but personally I didnt like the grave visiting thingie. but we enjoyed shopping n having a meal there. Walking is my favorite thing to do, we did a long walk from there.
Busy Busy Busy. I went on the day of Arafat, it was so busy women were sitting on top of one another at the time of prayer, Nice friendly place once we actually found Ayup

The real orient (almost) in the midst of Istanbul. A must for anyone visiting Istanbul who wants to get a feeling for the city's Ottoman and Islamic history. The mosque is interesting as one of the rare examples of oriental baroque - o.k., not 100% oriental, but that must have been always the charme of this glorious city. People here are much friendlier towards non-Muslim visitors than in the arch-conservative Fatih district. Go there on a Friday and you will meet Turks from anywhere coming to pray at this special place - and even then you should find your table in one of the nice coffeehouses.

Old beautiful mosque. An amazing experience visiting the Abu Ayub Al Ansari mosque. Not only the beauty of achitect but also by the overwhelming feeling of peace and serenity. A blessed place indeed. The people there too, seemed calm and reflective. Felt honoured being here. Will hope to visit here again son.

An authentic place to visit in Istanbul. Eyup is not a typical tourist location. On the contrary with its mosque as basic atraction is aplace for religious muslims. You can visit the place after taking the ship of Halic from Eminonu. This is a pleasant mini cruise of Istanbul's 'golden Horn".

Interesting mosque. There weren't many tourists when we arrived, only locals or pilgrims. We thought the religious service was done when we entered it and realized that was still in session. We had to go to the upper level, reserved for women, through a narrow staircase. It was interesting to see.

Cannot be missed. Eyup is such a great place to visit, there where you can have an amazing view up from the top of the hill and then through the large tomb which you cross till you reach down where the sultan's mosque is locatedA wonder place to visit and that cannot be missed as I mentioned before.Thank for your time to read my review.

Not to be missed. Not only does Hazrat Ayub Ansari have a significant status in Islam but the Sultans of Turkey have built a beautiful mosque too where he is buried It's hard to reach and it's pronounced as Eyup rather than Ayub To reach there I took bus 99 near galata bridge near spice bazar ( which Is 10 minutes Walk from Grand Bazaar ) And I guess it's about 6 or 7th stop from there and about 10 minutes ride

Eyup. This is not a typical destination for non-Turkish tourists, but that made it all the more intriguing. I've been twice, the first time we hired a small boat and cruised up the Golden Horn to the mosque. As we walked along the grounds it seemed deserted on that day, but once we reached the mosque we were the only obvious foreign faces in the crowd.It is a place of pilgrimage for Turkish Muslims. They come to pray and are instructed not to pray to objects (relics, tombs, etc), but only to Allah.There are nice restaurants in the area, as well. My first trip was in July, 2012, and my second was by tour bus in September of the same year. The tour was organized by our language school.
historical. The area was well preserved. The people are friendly we enjoyed visiting the Camii. It is a short cab ride from sultanahmed.

far from sultanahmet but superb!. it's really far from the main touristic attractions but it is worth visiting this mosque and its complex.I even saw a 8years old child whitedressed as if he were a prince: it was his day of circumcision. If you have enough time visit it.

Spiritual Place. One of my favorite place in Istanbul... to run from tourist places, to have peaceful moments with your own soul... praying inside the mosque... asking the Sultan on behalf of us to Allah.. sharing with others these moments... listen to Quran & Athan as well... I think it's a spiritual place for anyone muslim or non muslim...

View from the hill was great. Far away , not easy to reach this location, we where not go inside as our intention is to go to pier loti by cable car near by this mosque, from out side looks beautiful, that time was crowded as is on prayer time

Amazing view from eyup and telfrek. Good place and there u can feel how much the turkish people like the islam and the men's of profet mohamad ( el sah )like this sahaba abu eyub el ansari who die there...when u pray there u remmber the masjed el aqsa and el qaaba in maka...alot of people there spucial women...the eria vrey clean and many shops and resturant there in cheep price...from there u can go walking to telfrek to see one of the best few to istanbul spicial in the evning..the telfrek ugually is full and u will lose alot of time wsiting for telfrek...so better walking bz there is eady way for walking 10 muntes...

History with connections to past individuals and the locals today. Quite a way out and on the other side of the river/inlet (The Golden Horn) from the big mosque attractions in Sutanahmet but we were with an organised 3-day tour and all the hard work was done for us; on your own this visit would be quite difficult but – the taxis are cheap. We arrived just after a thunderstorm and the place was alive with locals going about their worship, there was a bride arriving for her wedding and little boys done up in their white suits in preparation for the circumcision ceremonies; it was the only insight we had of a functioning mosque rather than a museum during our whole 3 days and a lot of visits to ‘museum mosques’. The service was over and the Imam was talking to his flock and there was absolutely no problem with us going in and we were even encouraged to take photographs – you got a real sense of Muslims being proud of their heritage and yet being respectful of yours and being welcoming towards you – a shame that is not able to be present in the larger and more touristic places. The inside is gorgeous, that almost goes without saying. The extensive graveyards are enthralling and, just like ours here in the West, some are severely neglected and overgrown. There is the tomb of one of the Prophet’s (Peace be on him) nearest military collaborators and everything is set in a working space for the inhabitants of this part of the city with fountains (we saw, relatively, so few during or visit), eateries, shops and everything the population needs for its everyday life and all with the mosque at its centre serving the community. A real insight into the life of a city-dwelling Muslim

The spiritual place where you can get peace of mind and heart. This place is always busy with people coming alone and with families. Asking the sultan to pray on behalf of them to God. A place for men to perform their ablution is inside the main entrance. The mosque is huge but is absolutely packed on Fridays. Amazing spiritual place and very holy. Truly a place where when you pray, the heart and mind feels peace.

One of the most beautiful mosques in Istanbul. well this was my last mosque to visit in my trip to Istanbul, It holds a vast space, there are shops that has Islamic theme (you know they sell scarfs, hijabs and praying hats for men etc) there were restaurants and cafes near by.many people where there, I saw more people than at the blue mosque, the interior of the mosque is not that different than most of the mosques in turkey, the decorations and paintings on the wall almost similar to all other mosques. it was great to visit it and pray Duhur in this mosque, on our way out they gave us free cold water to drink !! :D

Special place for Muslims. This is a mosque where one of the "Sahaba) prophet Mohammed was buried , Abu Eyub El-Ansari. If you visit the Pierre Loti by cable car you also visit the mosque. There are some shops in the area with good price.

Nice peaceful retreat. Unless you are a muslim or someone interested in Islamic and Arabic history you will not find the place interesting. However, if you are around the cable car of pierre lotto then you must visit this mosque. The mosque houses the tomb of Abu-Ayub Al Anasri one of the companions of prophet Muhammed. The mosque is in the middle of the most famous graveyard in Istanbul which is surrounded by some nice gardens and shops.

The cemeteries are amazing. This may not be the most touristic site but the mosque and the huge cemeteries surrounding it are fascinating. The town itself is a real change from the tourist areas of Istanbul and make taking the Golden Horn ferry worthwhile.

At the far end of the Golden Horn, and thus requiring a journey. The Mosque is impressive in itself, and doubly interesting because it is where young boys are brought at the time of their cirumcision (7 or 8 years). Above the mosque, and easily reached by a path, is a charming café, once frequented by Pierre Loti, with a wonderful view.

Spiritually uplifting experience.. An amazing experience visiting the Abu Ayub Al Ansari mosque. Not only the beauty of achitect but also by the overwhelming feeling of peace and serenity. A blessed place indeed. The people there too, seemed calm and reflective. Felt honoured being here. Will hope to visit here again soon.

A very spiritual experience. Took a taxi from Grand Bazar - paid 40 TL to get to Eyup Sultan Mosque. Alternate to taking the taxi is a ferry ride from eminonu and you can also experience the golden horn water way this way( I found this out later) .There is a bus going to Eyup Sultan as well but judging from the taxi ride , it will quite a long bus-ride.We arrived around 9 PM and the place was busy with locals visiting Hazrat Ayub Ansari's tomb (called Eyup Sultan by locals) . There are four excellent restaurants nearby (side by side) and a burger king and many other eatries. Its a great place to be. Besides Ayub Ansari's RA tomb there are few other tombs as well. Make sure you do your home work before you go there as there arent any guides to take you around.

Old beautiful mosque. I love the mosque with the old othmani design.
There is beautiful ceremony on Friday after prayer
Small shops near by

Eyup Sultan Mosque. We visit it in our previous visit in 2012'now again we go for zirat ,we find it very peaceful we offered our two prayers their and feel blessed again I want to go their,as Hazrat Ayup ANsari is the companion of Harat Muhmmad Mustafa May peace be upon him.we met a very nice person their who is our tour operate who take care of us like a family member ,my sister is on wheelchair he push her wheel chair by himself which was always push by me,but he did it himself and not allow me to do it,it's very kind of him .

Historical Mosque to visit. This mosque is the final resting place of Abu Ayub Ansari, one of the very close companion of the last Prophet (PBUH). It was his home where Prophet stayed when travelled to Madina. So for Muslims specially it carries a lot respect and importance. It also has very old graves of important people.

time of serenity. If you have a chance to be in İstanbul in Ramadan, you should definitely see Eyüp Sultan Mosque and feel the air with the crowd. In order to discover the charms, do not abstain from playing around the mosque towards call to evening prayer.

The Holy Site. Eyup is home to the holy site for Muslims. The mausoleum of Hazrat Abu Ayub Ansari, who was Prophet Muhammad's companion is here. Hazrat Ayub was killed here during the first Muslim siege at Constantinople. We came here by bus 99 from the Eminonu Bus Station as we had just missed the ferry and didn't want to wait another hour. It was about 5pm and it was the rush hour. On the way we saw the the old City Walls and other areas. After getting off the bus, there is a square and a little ahead is the mosque and the mausoleum. Maybe for other tourists its not a great attraction but for the Muslims it holds a lot of sanctity. Many a prayers are heard and accepted here. Its very peaceful There is a graveyard too. Some souvenir shops are along the way. We bought some small silver trays with a tomb like cover for 5TL. The Muslims must visit the Mausoleum.

Tomb raiders' must (kidding). Ayup Sultan's tomb and the mosque along with it, is one of the must see places you need to see if you want to complete a tour of old Istanbul. The Bazaar, food market and parks around it are also beautiful.

Great! Authentic Turky. HAzrat Ayub Ansaari was a Sahaba of the Prophet Mohammed sallalla hu alaihi wassalam. It was in his house that the beloved prophet stayed after entering Madina (Yathrib). The square looks a little like Madina square. It has the same peaceful feeling. Good and cheap restaurants in the area. There are a lot of other Sahaba in the area.

Historic sites. From ancient historical places that remind you of the past and ancient history and place contagious easy way to get with the presence of services and popular markets, restaurants and cafes Site is worth a visit
Nice location but .... Your friend or a place where the Prophet would recommend you to go.However, women in the courtyard of the mosque to pray I did not like.

Eyup Sultan Camii. Very spiritual place , significant in Islamic history for the resting place of one of the Prophet's companions. Beautiful internal features of the mosque, with upper balcony for ladies.

Mosque and Cable Car Visit a "must do". We got there by bus from Eminonou past Galata bridge which cost us about 1.25TL each on the Istanbulcart, , alternatively you can go by taxi which is about 25TL or by ferry from the same location . After visiting the shrine , praying for deceased and doing Salah in the Masjid you can look around in the bazaar area(or do this before the shrine) , but if you are pressed for time or not there for religious reasons get in the queue for the cable car which costs about 2 TL on your Istanbulcart..the views during the ascent are amazing . At the top after a photo shoot , tea or ice cream you can walk down through a very interesting cemetery or catch the car down for which the queue was relatively short .Overall a wonderful experience.

Not to be missed. If you want to see a typical Islamic Pilgrimage site and a great market. Don't miss this site. You can reach it by car, bus or my favorite way by Ferry.Visit the Mosque and please, dress appropriately, it is a Holly Site. No shorts, no short sleeves, and a scarf to cover your head. You might follow my advice, being a Turk, living in the USA and taking along a lot of friends to see Istanbul, I advise them to put a T-shirt and carry ALL THE TIME, in their bags, a light weight long sleeve cardigan and a scarf. This way you are always ready to visit a mosque if you so wish, and there are so many! And please, NO shorts.Then visit the tomb of the Saint, he is known to accomplish all your prayers and wishes. He was the Banner Bearer of our Prophet Muhammed (pbuh).Then go to the market. Best place to buy Rose Oil or Jasmine Oil. And beautiful Head Scarves with OYA (hand made by crochet of flowers or other lovely decorations). I always buy dozens and bring it back to the US as gifts and everyone loves them. They go for about $ 5 each and you get a baker's discount for buying many!DO eat the ice cream there, it is scrumptious, especially the KAYMAK (Turkish Speciality made with milk, sugar and Pine Tree gum) and the VISNE (Sour Cherry) even better than Italian Gelatos!From there proceed to the Funicular and go to Pierre Loti Cafe. Or if you have good legs walk the path up. You will see amazing old tombs and lovely vistas. There is also a beautiful Nakshbandhi Tekke (Sufi Monastery of the Naksbandhi Order), a must stop and see site. The Gate Keeper Dervish will be happy to answer all your questions.You will eventually reach the little cafe, this was the favorite place of the French Writer who wrote a lot of books on Istanbul. Once there you will understand why, the view of the Golden Horn is amazing. Don't forget your camera!Above, short walk from the Anatole France Cafe, there is a great restaurant with excellent food and view.Don't forget to stop and pray at the tomb of a Sufi Saint just before the entrance of the Restaurant.There you can also enjoy a Narguile (Turkish Water Pipe), don't leave Istanbul without trying at least one!!!

Great place for photography. you can get into this lovely town by boat. very attractive and clean town indeed. The mosque is in the heart of heart of the town, you can't it miss it. Take the cable car to the top for unforgettable view of Istanbul. The cafe at the top is a bit pricey so buy your drink and sandwich before you ride the cable car.

Make the Pierlotti+Eyup Sultan in one day. My advice: go to Pierlotti area which is located on a small hill, use the telefric to go up (4 lira per person, and you can use the bus/tram/subway card), visit the Pierlotti area, then descend to sultan eyup on foot, the scenery is wonderful and the steep road is shaded by trees, until you reach the mosque, visit then have lunch in any of the many restaurants down there.
surrounded area is very good. too many tourest too many restourant too many shops, mosque it self is old but great i like this place

A totally local experience. This mosque is not usually listed as one of the must-see mosques; however, if you are interested in seeing a more local and much revered place of worship, this is it. Eyub Sultan; also known as Eyub Ensari (Ayub Ansari) was the companion of the Prophet Mohammad, in whose home the Prophet had stayed when he left Mecca for Medina. According to some this is the 4th most sacred site for Muslims after Mecca, Medina, and Jerusalem. Hazrat Eyub's tomb is in front of the mosque. One hardly sees tourists here but its an interesting place to people-watch.
Local place. This mosque maybe more popular than Blue Mosque for the local people. We saw many people waiting for visiting Saint Eyup's tomb in the inner court.

A nice a quiet place. Eyup Mosque is near Pierre Lotti caffe. We arrived by ferry from Eminonu. The mosque is near the ferry doc. The place itself is very impressive. We couldn't visit the mosque inside due to some renovations that were going on. We have visited Eyup sultan turbesi, where the people were waiting on line to pray. I think that at the time we were the only non Muslim people. It was very nice that they have dresses so women can enter and visit the tomb.I know that this Mosque is one of the holiest place for Muslims and everything showed and felt like, this. I hope that next time to visit the mosque inside.
Stunning. I loved to visit these mosques and this was on my list, another amazing space, don't forget there is more to the complex than just a mosque, the whole concept is amazing...

Busy busy. We went on a what must've been a religious bank holiday as it was teeming with locals in carnival mood. The boat trip to get there was pleasant and good to be out in the air away from the city. We didn't bother with the cable car up the hill but walked a back way seeing more of the town,which was unremarkable in truth. Mind you on our way down again saw the size of the queue for it we were glad we had walked. Lovely views of the Golden Horn & beyond from Pierre Loti,although trying to get a tea & a table was a struggle. The mosque itself was less exquisite than others we had been to but good to see so many pilgrims enjoying clearly what was an important day for them.

Avoid end of the day. The mosque itself is not very special, but the historical importance is worth the visit. Tombs of the most important ottomani heroes can be found there.
The tombs close at 5pm so watch the time of the visit. It was also extremely crowded around end of the day with religious pilgrims and people waiting for the iftar time.

very crowded and close to pier loti. This is one of a historical mosque in Istanbul and also there are some graveyards of masters. You should think twice before visit in Ramadan. Eyup is very popular place for being in Ramadan. Especially after 5pm, people go to Eyup.Pier Loti is attractive place. You should go to see there if you are in Eyup Sultan Mosque. Don't need to wait queue for cable car. It takes less than 10 min by walking. When you get Pier Loti if you want to sit a little for a cup of tea, don't be shy to get a table. Tea garden is crowded too and people are racing for table.

Excellent Mosque and its complex. Nothing more to add to the comments indicated here,for any moslem,this is one of the musts in İstanbul.As Fridays will be very very crowded,pls make yr planning accordingly.İt is about 30 minutes boat ride fm Karaköy and Eminönü by Şehirhatları and easy to locate this complex.We strongly recommend this place.

A living history. The tomb goes back to 1400 years ago but its being revived every day. with children dressed in special uniform coming to visit and offer prayers . It a chapter of European hisotry one should know while in Istanbul. Dont miss!

Different Mosque Experience. Everything here was free, unless you buy some food or cheap souvenirs or shell out the 1 TL for the public restroom. The mosque and surrounding areas were packed with praying muslims, many obviously travellers on some kind of pilgrimage. Tents were set up in the nearby squares with Imams giving sermons, and the park benches were filled with old men chatting and playing cards. The tomb/viewing area of Eyup El Ensari was open, filled with the devout praying, so we got just a short view before moving on. The mosque itself was also packed with more praying muslims, and there were only a small handful of discreet tourists like us lurking about. We stayed in the back as there was a call to prayer going on, with the singer in the raised seat next to one of the columns speaking into a microphone. It was a great chance to see real muslim worshippers in action, not just the tourist-packed throngs of the more famous mosques. The men were in the bottom center area, the women were confined to the sides and the upper gallery. The only downside was that the mosque was so packed, even next to the door the smell of shoeless feet was overpowering. Like bigger mosques, they have clothes and scarves to help you cover up before going in. You can walk through an Islamic cemetery or take a cable car up the hill to the Pierre Loti Cafe for the view at a public viewing station, but actually patronizing the touristy and overpriced cafe is optional.

Tranquil and Spiritual. Away from all the touristy hustle and bustle, this mosque was quite special and tranquil. Sadly the tomb area of Eyup (Ayyub) al Ansari was being renovated, and were allowed no access in. Nevertheless, the mosque is worth visiting! (According to security: renovations will last a year!) We spent hours taking in the peaceful surroundings and enjoying local friendly banter. Make your way to Pierre Loti from here to enjoy the spectacular views and a good cuppa apple tea!
a must see. a nice mosque within a small shopping are with nice restaurants and a must see as it is not that busy with tourists thus good for viewing

The Mosque and Mausoleum of Eyüp Sultan. The Mosque and Mausoleum of Eyüp Sultan, located outside the corner where the land walls meet the walls along the Golden Horn, is considered a sacred site for Moslems. Eyüp-el-Ensari was a standard-bearer of Mohammed and he died-here during an Arabic siege of the city in the 7th century. His grave was discovered at the conquest and later the mausoleum and the first mosque in Istanbul were built on this site. The original mosque was destroyed in an earthquake and the present one was constructed in its place in 1800. On Fridays, holy days for Islam, throngs of the faithful visit the mausoleum. The old trees, flocks of pigeons, the praying believers and the visiting crowds create a mystical and colorful atmosphere around the mosque and the mausoleum. The walls of the mausoleum in the courtyard are covered with tiles from different periods. Historical sources indicate that in Byzantine times this district was also a holy site where people came to visit the grave of a saint and to pray for rain during times of drought. The sultans succeeding Mehmet the Conqueror completed their coronation and sword-bearing ceremonies with a visit to the Eyup Sultan Mausoleum. The vicinity of the mosque and the neighboring hills are occupied by cemeteries. The famous Pierre Loti Cafe is also in this district. The well-known poet and author Loti was enraptured by Istanbul and he came here often to watch the beauties of the Golden Horn of those days. The view from this small cafe and the terrace, particularly during full moon, leaves long-lasting impressions on the visitors.

Great area. We arrived here on using the government ferry Sehir Halic which cost 3tl one way/person.Boat ride was nice and only took 30min on a scenic route. The mosque and main area is only walking distance from the ferry terminal.The mosque has a very spiritual feeling as unlike other attractions doesn't have tourists posing for photos.This mosque has the resting place of the famous companion of the prophet saw called Auyb Al Ansari.Many Muslims come here to pray for this companion. A must visit for Muslims.The area is nice and lively and has fountains, food places and a many shops. The items here are much cheaper than sultanhamet so you can come here on your last day to get some fresh backlava.Whilst here take the sky ride to Pierre Lotti and get the most magnificent view of the golden horn.Sky ride is only 3lira one way.

Crowded but beautiful!. We came to Eyup by ferry one afternoon since we were staying in Sultanahmet. The ferry was a little hard to find (it's on the extreme end past the new mosque).It's a nice scenic ride, about 25 minutes I think. The area is a heavily populated "overtly" muslim area. It seems like a safe, family friendly place. The mosque is pretty easy to find, and only a few minute walk from the ferry terminal. Despite some strange call to prayer (not the typical one--not sure what else they've added?!) the mosque itself was very crowded. I'm not sure if they're sufi here, or what denomination, but definitely some practices that are not in accordance with the teachings of the Prophet.Anyhow, definitely beautiful and well worth a trip here and Eyup in general. Pierre loti is a MUST DO. Stop for some tea and enjoy the view ;)

Spiritually Fantastic. Eyup Sultan Mosque has a very spiritual feel to it, those who would like to see the Islamic Way of life , head down you won't be disappointed. You can definatly tell that there is a Sahabi of the Prophet (SAW) laying there.

One of the great places I have visited. Although the place is undergoing renovation, but we were able to enjoy every corner of it. The place is very peaceful, full of birds and pigeons, you may wish to feed (pigeon food 1TL for a cup of corn or rice I guess). Muslim tourists may have a chance to pray inside the mosque and make a duaa for the prophet's companion Abu Ayub Al Ansari. Our visit was without a guide, we really missed lots of information about tombs and other parts of the place. We tried to ask locals but none of them were able to answer even those who speaks english.You can see locals bringing their kids who recently underwent circumcision, wearing very pleasant and traditional ottoman cloths. Good chance to have some nice shots of them or with them, people are very happy their and always welcoming to help.There are outer spaces with lots of fountains, that did not start until around 12 noon. So keep that in mind if you wish to have a good shot. I recommend to visit this place anytime of the week except on fridays because of the friday prayer and the place will be full, even the outer space of the mosque, no place for any tourist to visit.The place is full of souvenir shops, scarfs, antiques, food, and sweets. Mado is the best for sweets, located on the main streets on the main way to the mosque. I recommend you buy sahlep, some kind of sweets, very tasty full of cinnamon flavor and good during cold time. For narjila fans, who would like to smoke, you may find some restaurants offering it close to Mado. It is a very nice place to spend a couple of hours there.Keep in mind, no rest rooms in the restaurants, there is a public WC, it is ok, not bad, you should pay 1TL to get in. Merchants there are hardly negotiable, but do not give up, keep pushing them for discount, so you even end up kicked out of the shop or win the bargain.

Was in our tour itinerary. Being in a Muslim tour, we were taken there one morning. Unfortunately, the tomb of Ayyub al-Ansari was under restoration and we could only peer at it through a window. Best perhaps to combine the mosque with a visit to the top of the adjacent hill for the views / Pierre Loti cafe but we didn't have the time.

A real mosque. I visited Eyup mosque as the first place of my 19-day-Turkey tour.Tourists were rare,so I laterrealized that it was the real mosque.There were many people,most of them were muslims.It wasnot so large as the Hagia Sophia Museum nor Blue Mosque,but the atmosphere was reallypious.So if you want to see a real mosque,be sure to go there.And it is near the Golden Horn,walls of Constantinople.

Serenity. So old and so simple. The interior is absolutely beautiful and feels full of faith. (I'm not a believer, by the way!). You can walk up through the cemetery along a tree-lined path to Pierre Loti's teahouse at the top for a very reasonable apple tea with an amazing view.

Peaceful place. We spent an hour in this mosque, very spiritual place . We loved the mosque and the whole area. There are few tourists there . The place gives you fantastic feeling , you are far of everything and enjoying the peaceful place . I think it is a must visit place for muslims
Praying. The most spiritual place in Istanbul is the resting place of Abu Ayyub al-Ansari, known as Epu Eyyüp. If you're a Muslim, I urge you to pray fajr here in congregation; sublime.

Peaceful and Spiritual. A must for Muslim visitors. The mosque is beautiful. It's not filled with tourists but with locals. I loved serenity of the place. As of 19, May 2014 the tomb is closed for restoration. There are local bazzar behind the mosque, definitely worth checking out. I took the train from Sultanhmet to Eminonu (3TL) and then taxi to mosque (12TL). One the way back, tax to Eminonu cost (20TL) due to driver had go up 2K to make a U-turn.

peaceful. we visited Eyup Sultan Mosque as it has religious significance, it is in a quiet area, and around the mosque is a beautiful local area which is not filled with tourists . It was so nice to spend time in this beautiful location..

Serene atmosphere. This is a religiously significant site for muslims as it is the resting place for one of the prophet's senior companions.The area has a tranquil beauty and although the site is undergoing restoration currently it is worth a visit.One can combine it with a visit to the Pierre Lotti cafe, which is just up the hill from here.

Spiritual center of Istanbul. Eyup Sultan Mosque offers a mini taste of Medinah with its spritual atmosphere. There are many nice local resturants nearby. A must for muslim visitor and a gem for orientalists. You can get there with a nice walk from Eminönü or using the Golden Horn boat ride or taxi.

A nice trip up the Golden Horn. We took the ferry up the Golden Horn to visit this mosque and then the cable car up the hill to the café, which was quite exciting, with excellent views at the top. We then walked down and caught a bus back.

Well worth a visit. If you are collecting mosque visits this is one that you shouldn't miss. Set well away from the main sights of Istanbul in a conservative Muslim area it has more atmosphere and authentic appeal than its more famous blue cousin. The area round about is packed with atmosphere and with locals. And you can reach it with a very pleasant sail up the Golden Horn on the Eyup ferry.

Go out of town and visit. Personally I think that this mosque is far more beautiful than Sultanahmet. It is a "local" mosque as well as attracting people from all over the city. But it has that "non-tourist" feel that is now lacking in the Blue Mosque. Eyüp itself is a calm and welcoming place and this can also be combined with a trip to Pierre Loti via the funicular for one of the best views in Istanbul

History amidst natural beauty. We took the ferry to the mosque and enjoyed an excellent view of Istanbul along the way. The mosque itself is in a green, hilly area outside the serious traffic of the city so the neighborhood is worth a trip in itself. The mosque is both gorgeous and holy; plus, even though it is still a working mosque, it is welcoming to respectful visitors. The adjoining cemetery is a must-see as well. Walk up and have a coffee at the top. It's a good hike, but there is also a cable car up. You could have lunch up there or down below in the mosque neighborhood, which has excellent restaurants—we are at Sadabat Kebap and enjoyed the usual amazing Turkish food. All in all, a wonderful day.

religious site. If you're muslim then this site is holy due to the person buried here. great atmosphere. lots of reverence. there is a tradition that before young boys are circumcised they are brought here all dressed up in finery to received blessings. If you're not muslim then you probably wont see the significance. we are muslim therefore we stayed there a long time.
Not touristic. I heard Eyup Sultan Mosque is one of the most important mosques for Muslimans. There were so many visitors but most of them were local people.

Historical value. A pretty little mosque located off an attractive plaza. It's more interesting for its historical significance (on the the Prophet's companions is buried there) than for its artistic merit.

Peaceful Place. Away from the crowded site of Sultanahmet area, this is a nice getaway.But, I would appreciate if the information in the mosque be written also in English..The bazaar around the small town were worth looking at!!
Second Great Camii. We we're there twice and very nice Camii not so big but very old historical Camii everyone has to go there visit that Camii...
Religious shrine. This is a revered place of pilgrimage for Muslims at the foot of the cemetery leading down from the Pierre Loti viewpoint.

Don't miss the mosque nieghborhood. One of the mosques I would have regretted not being to ... very nice from inside and ouside, not as decorated as the other mosques in the Istanbul but still has got it's unique feel. Spend some time walking into the streets next to the mosque for an unbeatable experience.

The most sacred place in Istanbul. The mosque was built to honor Eyup, the Islamic conqueror of Istanbul. His tomb and some other companions are buried in the mosque complex. Compared to other mosques, there seem to be more worshippers seen inside.
quiet and wonderful. you can visit this place by taxi as no available metro , nice and wonderful , you will also visit the nice shops and bazaar around then go to pierre loti cafe

Tomb under resortation when visited. The Eyüp Sultan Mosque is sacred place as it holds the remains of Abu Ayyub al-Ansari, the companion and standard bearer of the Prophet Muhammad. As part of the Arab Army during the first attempt of the conquest to capture Constantinople he was killed during the action and was buried here. You will not find all that many tourist visiting even though it is close to the center of Istanbul. Unfortunately on my visit on the 13th March, the tomb area and outside wall was undergoing restoration. You can see the tomb through a glass window and the facade of the tomb which is covered in Iznik tiles was all covered up. The main mosque is still open for pray and visitors.There is public transport to Eyup from Eminonu including ferry or bus. We opted to go via taxi and it was only 12TL.

The mosque is located next to Pierre Lotti Hill. Pierre Loti was a French writer, who was called a "Turkholic", according to story he was in love with a Turkish girl living near this area, and therefore he used to visit this cafe every so often, that's why Turkish people called this hill after him.The mosque is located at the utmost upper corner of Eyup District and Golden Horn, one can take great shots from this point.

A moving experience. Hazrat Abu Ayyub Al Ansari (RA) also known as Eyup Sultan in Turkey was a very impotant companion of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and also my ancestor. Visiting his mazar to recite fatiha and see the masjid was a very moving experience. This is also the place the Sultans used to come for their coronation. A must go for the spiritual tourists.
Cute. I just went out of necessity but it was not really one of the more exciting places. I wouldn't call it a must-see but when in Istanbul you may as well.

Spiritual site with wonderful ambience. This is one of the holiest sites for Muslims from this part of this world. The mosque and its surrounding neighbourhood is a hive of activity with a lot of local flavour. There was no busload of tourists and you get to observe rituals and activities associated to the holiness of the site. Many Muslim pilgrims came to pay respect to Eyup Al-Ansari's tomb. The praying area was full and we did not get the chance to see the interior. We met a smiling boy who was dressed up as a young Sultan as part of his circumcision ritual. Have a walk around the bazaar outside the mosque and take in the sights and sounds of day to day Istanbul. Don't forget to try a Turkish beverage, popular during winter, called Boza (fermented wheat served with cinnamon and roasted chickpeas)

spiritual old mosque. We went to this spiritual old mosque with family.I liked it too much for its old architecture and lovely atmosphere.Many muslim people go there as pilgrims.There are many shops around.

so great place. we went to it using boat from eminunou to the mosque then telefrique to perlotti coffee really the location is so nice and I would like to stay long time in it and around the mosque down from telefrique there is shops with nice prices

very historical place. Loved the whole atmosphere there, very peaceful loving. Many of the locals love visiting this place. Tourists try to avoid Fridays/Saturdays, very busy place. Taxi ride from Old Town (Sultan Ahmet) took approx. 20 minutes.
very spiritual. there are works going on the at the moment. the mosque and surrounding areas are worth a visit. make sure you have few hours to spare to explore the area.

The best one. This my favourite mosque in Istanbul, take a walk and enjoy.
It is also great at night...but we got lost when we where going to other site because there is almost non city light in little streets around.
Beat of the best. What to say about this no word.Best nice little far aweay from the centar but take a bas and go to see a mosqe its unike no word to say.

go to the pierre lotti hill for the view, the mosque for the history. tips: go to pierre lotti hill to enjoy panoramic views of istanbul. u can even see hagia sophia on a clear day. walk down by the cemetery to eyup sultan mosqueeyup sultan is probably the holiest mosque in turkey. contains the tomb of one of the Prophet's Companions. the tomb itself is under renovation but its to be in the presence of an important person in Islam. the mosque is very historical as this is where the sultans conducted their version of a coronation. the mosques is beautiful. simple interioirs with arabesque and flowery designs on the dome. the mosques feels transparents due to many windows there. u can reach here from the pierre lotti hill (great view and pastry) and walk past a cemetery when people where buried as old as the 1600s to just last year.

Eyup Sultan Camii. Another great place to visit if you like to see another "face" of Istanbul: a face that is more traditional, a place where all women are covered and alcohol is not allowed at the nearby restaurants. When we visited this neighbourhood, we also covered our heads out of respect for the religious feelings of the locals. We had the great chance to see two little boys wearing their costumes after their circumcision. We had lunch at a nearby kebap-house that was full of turkish families enjoying their food.

Spiritual Visit. The mosque was modest but very spiritual. Visitors silently said prayers at the tomb of prophet's companion Saidina Ayub r.a. The surrounding area was full of shops. We cut short our visit because there were many beggars around.

Outstanding trip. This mosque is well worth the hassle of travelling away from the main tourist drags in Istanbul, as much for its surroundings as the building itself. Because the mosque has historic connections with a companion of Muhammad, it is a site of pilgrimage and is visited predominantly by locals and devotees. Just outside, is a lovely marble square with places to sit, eat and drink, and it has a very traditional feel to it. The interior is plain and lacks outstanding sights, but has a feeling of calm and spirituality difficult to find in the bigger mosques frequented by tourists. The easiest and most enjoyable way to get there is by the hourly ferry from Eminönü or Karaköy, as the mosque is only 5-10 minutes walk from the terminal.

Excellent experience. We passed by this mosque spontaneous after visiting Pierre Lotti. Really interesting visit with very few tourists. Explore a bit the alleys outside the mosque, there's a place that sells sheep.

A holy treat. Oppurtunity to pay tributes to one of the Companions of the Holy Prophet (Sallallahu Alayhe Wasallam) is a spiritual experience. The complex is small yet nicely maintained by the Turkish government.
a must see!. The Eyüp Sultan Mosque is the holiest site in Istanbul and one of the most sacred places in the Islamic world.

Holy and Brilliant. The tomb of the renowned Companion of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) Hazrat Ayub Ansari, at whose place the Holy Prophet (PBUH) first stayed when arriving in Medina. You can say prayer at the mosque and at the outside wall of the grave and the tomb. no collection of sand or nudging on the walls etc is allowed.. Only silent prayers of peace.

Beautiful Indeed!. Another mosque that is definitely worth making the trip to see. This is one of the oldest mosques and sits at the hills of the Golden Horns Cable Cars.I would also suggest that you take the ride up the cable cars and then walk the streets of Eyup. You'll be very pleased.

highly recommended. this is a v very important place for Muslims and those exploring history and religion. The grave of the companion of the Prophet Mohammed [PBUH] is probably the holiest shrine in Istanbul. There is little English writing around this site so do your research prior to the visit.

OUT OF THE WAY - BUT KEY. Go here to understand Eyup Ensari's part in Islam, assuming you have a good guild. Great example of Iznik tiles. Cemetery surrounding filled with great stories. Yup, depends on guide. Take the walk up to Pierre Loti Cafe. Uphill all the way, but worth the view.
Great Quite Corner. If you like to spend time relaxing without noise like Taksim, I highly recommend to go to Eyup Dis. its so quite with nice gardens and fountains, great place for Shisha

A great Sahabi (R.A). The mosque is besides the tomb of Hazrat Ayub Ansari (R.A) a great Sahabi. The camel of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) stooped in front of the house of this Sahabi when the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) migrated from Makkah to Madinah. The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) stayed at his place then.The bazar and sitting area besides the mosque and tomb is very nicely kept by the management and is very good for sitting and enjoying the place. It also offers a quite a few restaurants for nice traditional food.

Atmoshere excellent,people friendly. The moque is wonderful.However the area here is just excellent.Spent an evening here.The shops in the area around here are cheaper than sultanahmed and people are very friendly.We took the cable car up to Pierr Lotte and the view from there is stunning.P.S The tram does not stop here,so we went to main bus station in Eminunu and took a bus to get here.

is not the greatest sight. is not the greatest sight , but has a lot of great shopping to do on the main street , and yeah there is a Very nice View on the top of the hill at the restaurant ,,,,,, But cost a lot of cash to drink and eat....

More than a mosque. Best way to reach here is to first visit Miniaturk in the morning. Spend 2-3 hours there. Walk into the nearby waterfront. Hire a 3-4 seater power boat to Eyup Sultan. These boats go only there and nowhere else. This short ride is very enjoyable.We were guided to this by Aaamir, manager of Divalis Hotel, for which we are thankful to him.The place is named after Ayub Ansari, a companion of Prophet Mohammed(pbuh), who is buried here and a huge mosque attracts lots of visitors. There is a cable car station nearby to take you uphill for a enjoyable sight of the great city from mountain top. One side of the mountain is a grave yard with neatly built grave stones with names engraved. Cable car is very popular with tourists hence be prepared to que up for an hour or two to get your turn.

HONORED BY ALMIGHTY ALLAH. It was a honor given to me and my wife by the Almighty Allah to recite Fateha and spent whole day at the Tomb and Mosque .Probably one of the most spiritual places in istanbul where the eyup sultan mosque is adjoined with the tomb of the great companion of the prophet is buried. A once in a lifetime opportunity to do pay respects and do Fatihah at the tomb. Unfortunately the tomb itself Is currently closed due to renovations so can't wait to come back once complete. The surrounding Area is buzzing with locals and shopping for Islamic art is much cheaper here. We got a taxi (40 L) from the President Hotel, Beyzit which dropped us right outside the mosque. Taxi Drivers r like taxi drivers all over the world so what to comment .May Allah gives us againa chance to be at the tomb . there is a peace for me .Ameen

Great spiritual experience. Visiting the tomb and cami of Ayub al ansari was a truly spritual experience. the view from pierre lote via canle car is awesome . Experienced a truly turkish way of life at the cami

amazing spirituality. buried here is the host of Prophet Muhammad, enjoy the spirituality of this mosque and also number of shops to purchase islamic gifts, also in the vicinity are graves of other famous companions of prophet Muhammad

Amazing, spiritual, a taste of authentic istanbul!. Probably one of the most spiritual places in istanbul where the eyup sultan mosque is adjoined with the tomb of the great companion of the prophet is buried. A once in a lifetime opportunity to do pay respects and do fatihah at the tomb. Unfortunately the tomb itself Is currently closed due to renovations so can't wait to come back once complete. The surrounding Area is buzzing with locals and shopping for Islamic artefacts is much cheaper here.We got a bus (3l each) from the station at emoinou (galata bridge) which dropped us right outside the mosque. Got the bus back as we'll....takes 25mins only.....make sure you get a local to pay for your bus fare on their swipe card as the bus won't take cash although our driver let us on.
splendid view from the cafe. Nice place with a fantastic view over the Golden Horn. You can take the cable car up and the walk down through the cemetary.
must see!. Lots of history behind this mosque. Very old building and the architecture is stunning. Very near Golden Horn, so 2 sights for the price of 1 taxi ride!

Second Most Favourite Spot in Istanbul. I've been in Istanbul for about two months now and this is my second favourite spot I've visited so far. It's a very relevant, beautiful spot that's quieter than other tourist sites. Situated at the end of Golden Horn, it's a nice ferry ride to get there, once you arrive at the Eyüp Dock just follow the crowd across the street and you'll find it, gleaming white and somewhat magical!

Important site. Very important mosque to be ,in fact it is considered one of the most important spot for Muslim visitors who are coming to Turkey from all over the world visited then have a cup of authentic turkish tea at pierre lotti cafe on top of the hill to get a magnificent view of the golden horn at sunsetA must visit
Peaceful.. Very historical place for Muslims.Plenty of places to eat and lots of shops nearby selling all sorts.

Eyup Cami. Great place to explore the cultural costumes. We went there on a Friday and saw people celebrating and praying. The location is beautiful viewing the golden horn. We were luck to watch a turkish band playing old turkish songs free to the public.

very pleasant experience. like the place, the buildings, thearrangements & areas around
dislike accessibility via public transport is not easy
Excellent. I loved it in here. It takes time to come here but the visit is entirely worth it. Lovely feeling there. So spiritual, such an important place in Islamic history.

Eyup, The Telefrik ascent and a Meal. Eyup's magnificient location is an attraction that most tourists miss.The high location gives an opportunity to see a breathtaking view of the golden horn.Go up using the Telefrik, and down walking to catch the pleasure of walking a semi-jungle.Have a meal in the restaurant up the heights, the food is OK.If you are lucky, you can see the two engine 8 seat biplane which has been taking passengers to Bursa for decades, just skidding and taking off. Another suggestion for a trip to Bursa, but that's another story.walid

most revered mosque... at this most historic mosque lies buried, in its precints, perhaps the most revered and historical Islamic personality, Hazrat Ayub al Anmsari whom the Beloved Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him spent seven months withTherer is a huge clamour to see the grave of this most Noble Perssonality but a trip there especially to make duaa (lieft hands in prayer) is a must!!!

Historical site of the grave of Abu Ayub Al-Ansari. The mosque was built later but the location originally serves as the grave of Abu Ayub Al-Ansari. This is a place to visit simply to give salam and pray for the soul of a companion of the Prophet Mohammed (Peace be upon him). The mosque is of course lovely to see and the area outside the mosque which is enclosed by the mosque on one side and the bazaar on the other side is very nice.

Eyup to get to Pierre Lotti. I went to Eyup Mosque from Eminonu by the ferry which takes about 40 min to get to the famous cafe Pierre Lotti, as soon I got from the ferry I crossed the road to the Eyup Mosque square it has a few stalls which sells souvenirs and some local gifts. The easy way to get to the cafe is the stairs behind the cemetery and the views are really outstanding when you get to the top.

the best way to get there. From Eminonu tram station walk toward the Calata bridge pass all the boat fish hotel then pass the bus stand keep on the shore of the golden horn and you reach the Sehir Haltari Koshk it coast around TL2 on your Istanbul Kart by ferry check their timings, the Mosque is the forth holiest place for Muslim Turks after Mecca , Medina and Jerusalem..very peaceful and spiritual site, You may in counter some little boys dressed in white like a sultans on their way for circumcision or a newly married couple in their wedding outfits , or newly born babies to get blessed..must to see, then 3 min walk and catch the chairlift to Pierre Loti Café other TL2 on your Istanbul Kert and see Istanbul from the top hill and enjoy tea in its cafe..

Small and busy. This place was crowded. The tomb of the sahaba is at this mosque, but was being restored while we visited so there wasn't much to see. My husband enjoyed the prayer that he attended there and the surrounding neighborhood was nice to walk through.
Sultan Mosque. Was lost for words at the beauty they had that many centuries ago. It is amazing the intricate patterns and mosiac tiles coloura are mind blowing a must see.
Dawn Prayers - beautiful at this mosque. Espescially beautiful if you can be ther for dawn prayers - all the birds join in with a dawn chorus
Nice history. This place really contain historical value very much. Besides for the sightseeing place, this is the place for pilgrimage.
Pretty mosque, some construction now (July 2013). This is a pretty mosque which is easily included in a trip to see Chora. I'd pop by on the way to the Pierre Lotfi cafe.

A Golden Horn ferry trip to Eyup. We caught the local ferry and sailed up the Golden Horn to Eyup and the Sultan Mosque. The day we travelled there it appeared to be a local festival or day of religious importance. It was very busy with local people and a service was taking place when we were there. We were therefore unable to enter the Mosque and withdrew so that we did not disturb the celebrations. The exterior is in keeping with other Mosques. Eyup is a district different from the historical centre of the city. It has a 'holiday' feeling about it and the area is obviously by the inhabitants of Istanbul. It is well worth the (very cheap) ferry trip which we paid for using our Istanbulcard.

Inspiring. Went to the Eyup Mosque during Ramadan. It was crowded but just lovely. You can peek into one of the windows and see the tomb of Eyüp Sultan. It's a must see in my opinion. You can then walk up to Pierre Loti for a tea and enjoy the beautiful view overlooking Istanbul.

Worth the travel out of the "city" and the price is right. This was our first Mosque and loved that is wasn't one of the tourist ones - it was free! This active Mosque has a very interesting cemetery and Ottoman-style streets nearby. There was a religious celebration for young boys while we were there that was informative. There is a cable-car also that affords a most beautiful view of the city and takes you up to a cafe where you can get in the shade and enjoy a cup of tea.

so far. it's so far from old city and crowded on friday. after your visit to mosque take a turkish tea at pierre loti coffee house. it's just above the mosque with a beautiful scenery. also don't forget to hop on cable car for more beautiful view.

To observe the religiosoty life in Istambul. Not only for the Eyüp mosque but for the neighbouthood named the same, the visit of Eyüp mosque is maybe one of the most realistic visit in Istambul area as this neighbourhood is very populous. The mosque is entirely used by the Istambul people as the sacred place it is and for that reason you will not find tourist annoying with their fault of respect or taking pictures anywere. You can see the families celebrating the Sünet ceremony and the just married brides sharing sugar with the people. This corner of Istanbul is undoubtedly the most religious emanating place. for those who like to go out of the massified circuits.

The most preserved mosque in Istanbul. This is the mosque where the burial of Sultan Eyup is locate., It's a small mosque with wonderful Islamic design and I think this is the mosque that had the mark of the Prophet's footprints here but when we went there it was closed. Very close by is Pierre Lotti Cable Rides which is 3 minutes walk from this mosque. On the downside, I feel the place hasn't been looked after properly or not properly maintained but still it is worth a visit for sure.
Pierre lotti Cafe in Eyup was amazing. A picturesque spot where u can enjoy a historical small cafe & enjoy the view of both sides of istanbul

A well attended camii.. This is one of the camii's that is always full. This area is the resting place of Hz Ayub Ansari...a prominent Sahaba and the flag bearer of the prophet Mohammed (SAW). It was amazing to see people come here from all over. Especially seeing an endless stream of newly weds coming for a blessing. Everyone including the local stores were very friendly and welcoming. I spent an evening there with the family and thoroughly enjoyed it. Well worth the visit.

A special and unique mosque. In contrast to the jingoism of Fatih mosque (the "conqueror's" mosque), this is a place for happy occasions (circumscisions, weddings) and for those with a need, the sick. All sorts of people come here, and there's a bit of a festive atmosphere outside. Inside, because people with all sorts of needs come here, people are especially helpful and accomodating, even if you're not religious.

Must visit. The mosque is a beautiful place to visit. It's is one of the most amazing buildings in Istanbul. Before you enter buy some seeds to feed the doves. Kids will absolutely love it!! After you finish your tour I recommend going on a telepherique to the Pierre Loti cafe which offers panoramic views over the Golden Horn.. Really nice.

Beautiful place to visit. A must to visit because of its history. Eyup Sultan Mosque, is where a companion of the Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) is buried, around 1400 years ago. It holds amazing value and esteem and should be visited

Get off the beaten path.. Enjoy the ferry ride up to Eyup and visit the small town which is a magnet for pilgrims. The people watching is fantastic, as is the tram ride up to an coffee stop with a magnificent view.

Fantastic. Highly recommended to take the Golden Horn Ferry to Eyup and then visit this shrine as well as take the cable car to the top of the hill (it's then best to return to the mosque by walking back down through the very interesting cemetery as opposed to dealing with the long return lines for the cable car). The shrine itself was our favorite mosque in Istanbul and the surrounding market stalls offer better prices than elsewhere in Istanbul.

Very important place for devout Muslims. It is very important Camii and a burial place of Sultan Eyup who was a standard barrier and Prophet's companion in early Islamic wars. This Camii has been recently restored to its early glory.

A very normal mosque. You can visit this mosque when you are going to "Pier Loti" hill. The mosque itself has nothing interesting for a normal visitor unless you didn't see Blue mosque, Suleymanih mosque or Fatih mosque. but the area around the mosque is very nice for eating, drinking and more than that buying some gifts for your family and friends. Prices are more fare in this area.So, after coming down from the Pier Loti hill it worth to take a look at old Bazar in front of Eyup sultan mosque.

very peaceful. we went at night and people were praying and were giving people some suits celebrating the first days of receb . there were lot of restaurants and shops near by we spent a nice time exploring that nice area

Missing hints. Every time I visit that osque and pray in I find carpets smellyThe second point is the staff advising ladies to cover their heads and do not care their bodies , arms and legs are naked.The right thing is to show them the proper dress by pictures and do not allow violations as we do in Opera ( formal dress only). When you are ready you are welcome and if not you can only enjoy from outside ....

Very nice Mosque/Art. The plan of the building is basically that of an octagon inscribed in a rectangle. The main dome rests on four semi-domes; not on the axes but in the diagonals of the building. The arches of the dome spring from four octagonal pillars— two on the north, two on the south— and from piers projecting from the east and west...

Abu Ayoub Al ansari Mosque. A mosque and a tomb of the Abo Ayoup Al ansari where burred. The cable car is near and take you up the mountain to a good prize restaurant with a wonderful view to the golden Horn

A nice excursion. Take the local ferry out to Eyup from Eminönu and walk over to the mosque. It is not a touristy place but an important place of pilgrimage to Moslems and was beautiful inside. It was well worth the short journey away from Istanbul city centre and the town itself is interesting as a local area with very few tourists.

A very holy place. My Algerian husband explained that this Mosque, the burial place of one of the prophet Mohammed's companions, is considered the fourth holiest place in Islam. It is a much simpler style mosque than the Blue Mosque but still very beautiful. There were stricter rules in place as far as covering shoulders, legs and of course heads but that is to...

Very beautiful and in one of the last traditional neighborhoods. I visited the Eyup Sultan Mosque one afternoon and was encouraged by Turkish women to climb the stairs to their section above the main room. I had a scarf with me so there was no problem and I removed my Tevas. It was one of the best experiences I've had in Turkey and matched my friend's description of the beautiful...


More
Nice Mosque. the design and the architecture of this mosque is really wonderful..it is not a very big mosque but worthy to visit.

quite beautiful mosque. This is the one of my favorite mosque in Istanbul. the location is a little faraway from Sultanahmet area, I went to there by bus, it takes about 10min by bus. and I returned by ship. Many women visited there, more than another mosque. very quite, and very cozy place.

Don't miss it. This mosque is one of the most important for Muslims. The place is very popular because it was raised close to the place where the standard-bearer of the Prophet was buried. His name was Abu Ayyub al-Ansari, but his Turkish name is Eyup Sultan.
This mosque is a pilgrimage place, so you will see many people and many of them...


More

Is a mosque - have proper clothes. No bathing dress..
They might ask you to leave and come back In between prayer times. So go for a snack, plan a second thing to do instead of visiting a mosque. The sultans palace f e will easily take you several hours because there is so much to see not only the harem :-)

Amazing peace. Went there with few friends to offer Fateha.
Small, clean ....not crowded but soooooo peaceful.
A few renovations were going on but trust me you can feel the energy from that place.
I wanted to just stay there but had to catch up with my other friends.
I don't know why but I had goose bumps while I was there....


More

Go on a Sunday if you can. We were disappointed that the renovation work meant that some of the mosque was closed. But it is really worth going to. Visit some of the cemeteries that surround it. And do go on a Sunday, when the place is teeming with little boys dressed up in amazing costumes and visiting with their families before going to be circumcised.
Must Pay A visit. For muslims if you r going to istanbul you must pray Fatiha at Hazrat Ayyub R.A grave who was the companion of Hazrat Muhammad S.A.W.W.

Under Construction. The facilities are undergoing refurbishment. The construction does not seem to bother the locals who continue to flood the Mosque. The grave is visible through a window and the mosque remains open.

A fantastic alternative to the Blue Mosque. Whilst in Istanbul we visited several Masjid (mosque) to attend the daily prayers. What I loved about this particular Masjid was the friendly family atmosphere that surrounded the whole place. For those that don't know, this Masjid acquires its name from one the companions of the Prophet Mohammed (peace be upon him) Eyup Sultan lived in Medina at the time when the Prophet entered the city and he rested at his house. Eyup Sultan's burial place sits across the courtyard and although currently undergoing renovation the whole area was teaming with local visitors paying their respect.If you can try and visit at Sunday lunchtime when unlike other Masjid's at prayer times this place is full with the courtyard being utilised as well .There are also the resting places of other companions within a short walking distance which we also visited. All in all a fantastic afternoon for delving into some Islamic history.
space of a MIRACLES. Have you ever felt a smell of a miracle?if not, go to the Eyup Sultan Mosk. it's in the air, everyone is in mood of meeting miracle...

Must see!. A holy place indeed...Calm & soothing. The shops around have good traditional stuff with reasonable prices. Good restaurants, not expensive either. Just go to Iminuno station & take the Sultan Eyup autobus.. you will love it I promise :)

Beautiful mosque. After a while, the gorgeous mosques in Istanbul run together, but this is definitely a lovely one, and Eyup is a pretty little village/suburb, not hard to get to by bus. If you like history, read Roger Crowley's book on the final siege of Constantinople and you'll learn who Eyup was!

Beautiful. We went to Eyup to visit this mosque, it was so beautiful! There is a lot of history surrounding this, I just wish that some of the history was actually in english - nevertheless we still managed to get a translation of what was written. After the mosque we took a cable car ride to a pretty cafe called Pierre Loti - the views from the cafe was simly breath taking!! I would defo recommend a visit to the cafe after the mosque

Must see for Muslims. If your not Muslim I'd stick to the other mosques unless you want to see a less touristy area which this seems to be, there's a small bazar area near by as well. If your Muslim its a must see it is said that auyub RA is buried here (for those who need a refresher (I did) he's the one who when the prophet sws arrived to Medina and everyone wanted him to stay with them and he let his camel decide well this his the sahabah who's home he stayed at. It is very emotional and overwhelming to think a sahaba was actually there. They have actually erected a tomb here and ppl go make dua there (I found it a bit strange but I also don't know the culture/traditions, our tour guide told us some ppl "pray through him" which seems shirky and others seem to just be praying for him and paying their respects).
ok. more turkish the the other ones, really muslim atmosphere,not touristic, don't miss Pierre Loti cafè upstairs and the muslim cemetery
A different atmosphere.... Lots of foreign muslims come here for prayer, this is where Eyup Sultan is burried. This is very different from other parts of Istanbul, a must see !

Away from the city centre. 20 minute drive from the main Sultanahmet square. Once you reach there feels like you have come to an entirely different country. Perhaps because here is the real Istanbul. No one could utter a word of English here. Visited early morning so not much of a crowd. Restoration works were going on at the time around the grave of the companion of the Prophet. Eyup Sultan Mosque. I hopped in the bus no. 99A at Eminonu port bus station, cost TL1.50 - all the way to Eyup.The mosque complex is big and inside the mosque ground is the turbesi (tomb) of Abu Ayyub al-Ansari (Eyup Sultan) - the standard bearer of the Islamic prophet Muhammad. His tomb is greatly venerated by Muslims, with a lot of visiting pilgrims. People enter and offer prayers inside the blue tiled turbesi. It is constructed in 1458 by Fatih Sultan Mehmet, along with the mausoleum. The present mosque is constructed under the supervision of Huseyin Efendi in 1800. This mosque is the holiest mosque in Istanbul and one of the Islam's sacred place. Popular story tells that while serving as commander of the Arab forces during the siege of 668 to 669, Eyup was killed and buried on the outskirts of the city. The burial site was discovered during Mehmet the Conqueror’s siege on the city, although the tomb is mentioned in written accounts as early as the 12th century.

Top tips for visiting Eyup Sultan Mosque (Eyup Sultan Camii). Why is this town not listed as a must-visit place in Istanbul? Although the Eyup mosque is highly reccommended place to visit but nobody ever reviewed about the town on tripadvisor.There are so much more Eyup can offer than just visiting the mosque. This town probably has not been explored much by the tourists except the cemetery part, Pierre Loti cafe and the mosque. We accidentally chanced upon this town just a few kilometres away from Sultanahmet and Taksim square. I am going to give you a few good insights and tips about visiting the town as well as the mosque. Tip 1: how to get there? Take a local bus number 99 from Eminonu. It cost 2 - 3 Tl (lira) per person. The ride is about 20 minutes and make sure you stop a few stops after you past the second bridge. You will need to gauge it yourself unless you have a smart phone. Don't bother taking the ferry, taking a bus is so much easier and faster. Tip 2: if you want to see the mosque, get there in the morning because the crowd seems build up in the afternoon. We went there on a sunday. Tip 3: there are also a lot of old sultans' tombs along the way to the mosque and you are allowed to enter for free but make sure you take off your shoes to enter the shrine. Tip 4: start the cemetery walking trail near the mosque where shops were selling muslim robes and holy books. Tip 5: Since this is a place that attracts pilgrimage, there is of course a shopping street too. Do not miss out on the famous savoury pastry, Turkish Borek, that is sold in the shops (See picture). Out of so many Borek shops, we chanced upon this quaint little small borek shop which sells Borek for 1.25 TL per 100 gram if i am not wrong. You cannot miss it! Tip 6: while we were walking around the cemetery area, we also found out there is a huge local market at the hilly side of the town. It is very difficult to find but if you found it, you will not regret it. You can see the everyday life of the locals here especialy the hustles and bustles. If i could give you an exact location, then it would be near the Pierre Loti cafe. See picture. Also you can find the cheapest kebab here for only 2 Tl to 4 Tl. Tip 7: you can forget about going to the Pierre Loti cafe because if you did the cemetery walking trail, you can literally see the Golden Horn from the cemetery. Tip 8: just so you know, the traffic from Eyup to town (sultanahmet or taksim) will be quite bad because the turkish seemed to come out after 3pm during the day. make sure you plan your time ahead if you are heading to the airport. Excellent if you want more than a superficial look at tourist sites. The Eyup Sultan Camii is considered by Muslims to be the most holy place in Istanbul. It is the site of the tomb of one of the companions of the Prophet Muhammad. This mosque is worth a visit for those who want to see more of "real" life in Istanbul than just Sultanahmet Square. Because of the tomb, it is a site of pilgrimage for Muslims, and you will find both Istanbullus and people from other areas going to pay their respects. Within the mosque itself you can respectfully sit at the back (women upstairs) while people pray. The mosque has one of the largest women's sections of any mosque in Istanbul, with overflow areas when the crowds are too big for the balcony above the main section of the mosque, so for women it is easier to find an "out of the way" place to observe than at most other mosques. Because families come to the mosque together, there are usually mothers with young children in the women's area, and as a result, it's an interesting place to see how families manage their religious observance with their kids.The tomb is located across the courtyard from the main entrance to the indoor section of the mosque. When it is not under renovation, the tomb is open for visitors, and there are generally a lot of people inside praying. The veneration of Eyup Sultan is not technically orthodox in Islam, and as a result the sharp observer can see some of the differences between orthodoxy and "folk" or "popular" practices in Islam. Every religion has these, but they are often hidden to outside observers. This mosque is a good place to go to see the juxtaposition of orthodox and popular Islam.The mosque can generally be reached by bus or by ferry. The Eyup ferry terminal has been closed for repairs, and it's not clear how long these will take, so at this time the bus is the best option. It's worth checking the schedule, though, to see when the ferry terminal opens again, because the ride up the Golden Horn from the Eminonu terminal (just past the bus terminal and labeled Halıç) is very pleasant and inexpensive.Note that the mosque and tomb are likely to be packed during Ramadan.

Islam's fourth holiest site. Eyup Sultan Mosque is a place that should be on every travellers itinerary & is away from the tourists.You could take a boat trip along the Golden Horn (Halic in Turkish) - which is a smaller stretch of water than the Bosporus & less known to travellers - Golden Horn ferries leave Eminonu quay every hour during the day. You will be able to see a very different & more intimate side to Istanbul here. The boat passes the district of Fener - it's the old home to the city's Greek population with its sprinkling of Christian churches - & the boat makes its final stop close to the Eyup Sultan Mosque - Islam's fourth holiest site. The trip takes around 35 minutes.

Fascinating mosque, area and cemetery leading to it. we had not planned to go to the Eyup mosque but went to it after a visit to the Chora Church/Muzei and tea at the Pierre Loti Cafe. REAL MOSGUE FOR PRAY. Eyyp Sultan Mosque stands in Eyyup on the south end of the Golden Horn. The mosque is named in memory of Eyyup El-Ensari who was the flag man of Holy Mohammed. The complex which includes the mosque comprises a madrasah, an alms house, a soupkitchen and a bath. The grave of Eyyp El-Ensari which has been converted into a tomb is situated here as well.

Discover Istanbul with the locals. A visit to the Eyup Mosque is an amazing experience and you will really discover the spirit of the people of Istanbul as there is very few tourist. The Mosque and its courtyard is beautiful and there is a special section where you can walk through and offer prayers or just experience the peacefull atmosphere.When you visit the mosque consider a visit to the Pierre Loti cafe which can be reached by cable car and you will get a wonderful view of the Golden Horn with your cup of tea. The ferry departs from the left hand side of the bridge as you stood facing the Galata Tower. This is really a lovely day outing to discover a different part of Istanbul.

This is my second visit to Eyup masjid.... This is my second visit to Eyup masjid. The serenity of the masjid overwhelms you once you step into the prayer area.
