4th Most Important Shrine of Islam. This mosque, situated in a district called Eyüp which is almost an ancient and holy necropolis of Ottoman times, is considered the number 4 shrine of Islamic communities after Mecca, Medina and Jerusalem. Built in 1458, just 5 years after the conquest of Istanbul by the Ottomans, it also supposedly hosts the tomb of Ebu Eyyub Halid bin Zeyd el Ensari (one of the first supporters of Prophet Mohammad) who had joined Ummayads when they tried to conquest Constantinople in 7th century and this is what makes it that holy in religious meaning. Of course, the mosque itself has been renovated many times since its establishment but its simplicity has been preserved throughout the years. It's usually a very crowded area and especiallt last Sunday of every month, a very ancient Quoran is displayed here and those days, it's almost impossible to move around let along walk around. So it's better not to go there those Sundays.

Impressive, Beautiful, Holy and Real. I admit I was a complete tourist in Istanbul, but I'm always interested in getting away from touristy places to experience places and opportunities that are more a real part of any city that I visit. The Eyup Sultan Mosque is probably the most holy mosque in Turkey, and it is built right next to the memorial tomb of Eyup Sultan, with a small courtyard in the middle. This is definitely not a tourist place, or perhaps to be more precise, it isn't much of a tourist site for non-Muslim tourists. It is filled with people who are in contemplative prayer (male and female), and clearly it is a destination point for Muslims from many different cultures and countries. There are scarves available for women visitors, and plastic bags to carry shoes. The interior of the mosque is quite beautiful with a number of lovely windows looking into a very very old graveyard (with the most unique and interesting tombstones I have ever seen). Between the mosque and the highly-decorated tomb of Eyup Sultan is a lovely courtyard with a HUGE old tree that is hundreds of years old (the top has been lopped off but it is still very much alive, and very impressive). The tomb is very decorated, with beautiful tiles. It is small and packed with visitors. The actual burial memorial is roped off and in its own separate viewing room (it is very ornate and quite a sight to see). There were a number of women who were showing respect, and it felt wrong to jostle to the front to see better. In the back of the room, there is a small space that is roped off, with a line. In the wall is a case with a piece of marble. The marble is where Mohamed stepped at one time, and it's called the footprint of Mohamed, and it's quite popular to see. I really felt the power of this holy place, although I am not Muslim. I thought it was well worth a visit, and for tourists who want to see something that isn't really touristy, it was a pretty great destination. It was interesting and historic, and it was clearly a very important place for Muslims from all over the world. If you have free time, and the inclination to get off the tourist path, then I highly recommend going to see the Eyup Sultan Mosque.

Historic & Magnificient - a must place for muslims !!. Our hotel was in the Sultanhamet District but a 15min taxi ride (20TL) was well worth it. This is the resting place of abu ayyub al ansari (R), a very famous companion of the beloved prophet Muhammed (PBUH). The tomb can be very bust but wont take more than 15/20mins to get in - I dont recomend visitng it during Friday prayers. In the tomb is also a footprint of the Prophet Muhammed and alongside is the Eyup mosque.Outside of the Eyup Mosque are some bazaars which most of the locals use which i found alot cheaper and alot less stressful then the traditional Spice & Grand Bazaars. The bazaar immediately next to the mosque sells Islamic items such as scarfs, qurans, pictures and other Islamic items.Once you finish here i do recommend jumping onto the Cable Car to Pierre Lotti Cafe which has some amazing views of Istanbul for some refreshments. Its so easy and is all sign posted from Eyup Mosque and costs 2TL - from the Cable Car you also get a view of the ancient graveyard on the hill side.

Holy ground. Eyup sultan is one of the most conservative sections of Istanbul but a place that should be on every travellers itinerary. Away from the tourists, you get to see Istanbul as it must have been like for hundreds of years before Ataturk tried to turn it into a poor mans paris.Eyup sultan is the burial location of abu ayyub al ansari (R) the neighbour and friend of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him.) As such he is a legendary figure in early Islam and was part of the first Muslim legions sent to conquer Constantinople. When he was dying, he asked that his friends but his body on a horse and attack as far as they could and bury him deep within enemy territory. This they did and centuries later, the army of Mehmet Faith (the conqueror of Constantinople) found his grave and built the mausoleum and mosque at the site.Rich with history and charm Eyup Sultan was the location where the Sultan and Caliph were given the sword of Othman confirming them as ruler and the most holy place in all of Turkey.
